PREFACE
         This code of the Village of Hinsdale, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance O2025-36, passed September 2, 2025.
Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions
of this code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith.
Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular
provision of the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
                     American Legal Publishing
                     Cincinnati, Ohio
VILLAGE OFFICERS
The village of Hinsdale was incorporated as a village April 3, 1873, under an
act of the general assembly of the state of Illinois, entitled "an act to
provide for the incorporation of cities and villages", approved April 10, 1872.
A copy of the incorporation proceedings is included in the appendix.
The following is a list of village officials from 1873 to the present time. The
years represent the respective fiscal years of the village which began in May
of the calendar years designated:

ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not amend the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
 
 
ORDINANCE NO. O2025-31
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE VILLAGE CODE OF HINSDALE TO ADD A NEW CHAPTER 15
(PUBLIC SAFETY AND TRANSPORTATION COMMISSION) IN TITLE 2 (BOARD AND
COMMISSIONS) CREATING A PUBLIC SAFETY AND TRANSPORTATION COMMISSION
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Hinsdale (the "Village") is a non-home rule
municipality, having all of the powers and authority granted to such
municipalities pursuant to Article VII, Section 7 of the Illinois Constitution
of 1970, including the right to exercise any power and perform any function
pertaining to its government and affairs; and
 
WHEREAS, the Village President and Board of Trustees of the Village recognizes
the importance of addressing public safety, transportation issues, traffic
management, pedestrian safety, and infrastructure related safety improvements
within the Village in order to enhance the overall well-being, safety and
mobility of its residents; and
WHEREAS, the Village President and Board of Trustees have retained consultant
KLOA to conduct a multi-phase comprehensive Village-wide Pedestrian and Traffic
Safety Study to assess and provide recommendations regarding pedestrian and
traffic safety issues throughout the community; and
WHEREAS, the Village President and Board of Trustees find it advisable to
establish a Public Safety and Transportation Commission to, among other things,
review and evaluate the multi-phase Village-wide Pedestrian and Traffic Safety
Study from KLOA and to otherwise provide advisory recommendations to the
Village Board on matters related to public safety, transportation, traffic
management, pedestrian safety, and infrastructure-related safety improvements;
and
WHEREAS, the Village President and Board of Trustees recognizes the value of
engaging community stakeholders, such as representatives from the local Chamber
of Commerce and School Districts, in discussions related to public safety and
transportation planning; and
 
   WHEREAS, the Village President and Board of Trustees, in consultation with
Village staff, have proposed the creation of a new chapter 2-15 in the Village
Code of Hinsdale (the “Village Code”) establishing a Public Safety and
Transportation Commission, and find the creation of a Public Safety and
Transportation Commission to be in the best interests of the Village and its
residents.
 
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Hinsdale, DuPage and Cook Counties and State of Illinois, as
follows:
 
SECTION 1:   Recitals.  The foregoing recitals are incorporated into this
Section 1 by this reference.
 
SECTION  2:   Title 2 (Boards and Commission) of the Village Code of Hinsdale
is amended to create a new Chapter 15 (Public Safety and Transportation
Commission) to read in its entirety as follows, with additions underlined :
 
CHAPTER 15
PUBLIC SAFETY AND TRANSPORTATION COMMISSION
 
SECTION:
 
2-15-1: Creation; Purpose
 
2-15-2: Members; Liaisons
 
2-15-3: Terms of Office
 
2-15-4: Duties and Responsibilities
 
2-15-5: Meetings and Procedures
 
2-15-6: Staff Support and Resources
 
2-15-7: Sunset
 
 
2-15-1: CREATION; PURPOSE:
There is hereby created a public safety and transportation commission, whose
purpose is to review and evaluate a multi-phase Village-wide Pedestrian and
Traffic Safety Study created for the village by consultant KLOA, and to
otherwise provide input to the village president and board of trustees
regarding matters related to public safety, transportation, traffic management,
pedestrian safety, and infrastructure-related safety improvements. The public
safety and transportation commission shall serve in an advisory capacity only.
All recommendations or actions taken by the commission shall be non-binding and
subject to the review and approval of the president and board of trustees. The
commission shall not have the authority to make final decisions, implement
measures, or allocate or expend Village funds.
2-15-2: MEMBERS; LIAISONS:
A.   The commission shall consist of six (6) members who shall be appointed by
the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees.
Commissioners shall serve without compensation. The commission members shall
consist of the following:
1. Three (3) voting members, two (2) of whom shall be chosen from among the
then current members of the president and board of trustees of the village, and
one (1) of whom shall be a resident of the village with a background in either
traffic engineering, transportation planning, or public safety engineering; and
2. Three (3) additional non-voting members, who need not be village residents,
but shall be community stakeholders (i.e., persons involved in the Hinsdale
business community or affiliated with village educational institutions)
B.   The Commission shall be advised by village staff liaisons, who shall not
be voting members, and who shall be appointed by the village president in
consultation with the village manager, as specified below:
1. The police chief or their designee;
2. The village engineer or their designee;
3. The director of public services or their designee; and
4. The village manager or their designee.
The liaisons shall provide technical expertise and guidance regarding public
safety and transportation matters, including the multi-phase pedestrian and
traffic safety study. The liaisons, once appointed, shall continue to serve in
their roles at the discretion of the village president.
2-15-3: TERMS OF OFFICE:
 
A.   The terms of the members shall be as follows:
1. The term of office for the village president and board of trustee members
shall be two (2) years;
2. The term of office for the resident member shall be one (1) year; and
3. The term of office for community stakeholder members shall be one (1) year.
B.   Any vacancy among the members of the commission shall be filled for the
remainder of the unexpired term in the same manner as in the case of the
original appointment.
2-15-4: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The duties and responsibilities of the commission shall include, but are not
limited to:
A.   Reviewing and providing input on public safety and transportation-related
matters.
B.   Reviewing and evaluating a multi-phase Village-wide Pedestrian and Traffic
Safety Study created for the village by consultant KLOA, and periodic updates
to same, and making recommendations to the president and board of trustees
regarding same.
C.   Providing input in the development of long-term public safety and
transportation strategies that align with the village’s overall planning goals.
D.   Meeting as needed to discuss and deliberate on matters within the
commission’s purview, and reporting its findings and recommendations to the
president and board of trustees.
E.   Other duties as directed by the president and board of trustees from time
to time.
2-15-5: MEETINGS AND PROCEDURES:
A.   The commission shall meet as necessary at the call of the chair, or upon
the direction of the president and board of trustees.
B.   The village president shall appoint, on an annual basis, one (1) member to
serve as the chairperson.
C.   A quorum of at least two (2) voting members and a total of at least four
(4) total members is required for the transaction of official business, with
decisions made by a majority vote of the voting members present.
D.   The commission shall adhere to the rules and procedures established by the
president and board of trustees, consistent with the Illinois Open Meetings
Act.
2-15-6: STAFF SUPPORT AND RESOURCES:
The village shall, through its appointed staff liaisons, provide support to the
commission, including but not limited to providing relevant data, documents,
and research to assist in the commission’s review and decision-making. The
commission may also request technical expertise from outside consultants
subject to the approval of such expenditures by the president and board of
trustees.
2-15-7: SUNSET:
 
The commission shall automatically dissolve at 11:59 p.m. on the date that is
three (3) years after the passage of the ordinance approving its creation (the
“Sunset Date”) unless the president and board of trustees adopt an ordinance
before that time expressly extending or re-establishing the commission. After
the Sunset Date, and absent an extension ordinance, the commission shall have
no authority to meet or act.
SECTION  3:   Severability and Repeal of Inconsistent Ordinances.  Each
section, paragraph, clause and provision of this Ordinance is separable, and if
any section, paragraph, clause or provision of this Ordinance shall be held
unconstitutional or invalid for any reason, the unconstitutionality or
invalidity of such section, paragraph, clause or provision shall not affect the
remainder of this Ordinance, nor any part thereof, other than that part
affected by such decision. All ordinances, resolutions or orders, or parts
thereof, in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance are to the extent of
such conflict hereby repealed.
 
SECTION 4:   Effective Date.  This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect
following its passage, approval, and publication in the manner provided by law.
 
PASSED this 12th  day of August 2025.

ORDINANCE NO. O2025-34__
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 6-6-4 (LIMITED PARKING ZONES) IN TITLE 6 (MOTOR
VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC) OF THE VILLAGE CODE OF HINSDALE RELATIVE TO AN EXPANSION
OF THE CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT TIME LIMIT PARKING ZONE TO INCLUDE 2ND STREET
BETWEEN WASHINGTON AND LINCOLN
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Hinsdale (the "Village") is a non-home rule
municipality, having all of the powers and authority granted to such
municipalities pursuant to Article VII, Section 7 of the Illinois Constitution
of 1970, including the right to exercise any power and perform any function
pertaining to its government and affairs; and
 
   WHEREAS, the Village has previously, in Ordinance No. O2022-11, established
a Central Business District Time Limit Parking Zone. The limits of the Parking
Zone established have since been adjusted from time to time; and
 
   WHEREAS, in consultation with certain downtown businesses, and a review of
existing parking limitations and permitting in the area, Village staff
recommends extending the Central Business Limited Time Zone Parking to include
2 nd Street, between Washington and Lincoln; and
 
   WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees have determined that it is in
the best interests of the Village and its residents and businesses, to further
amend the Village Code to implement staffs recommendation by extending the
Central Business District Time Limit Parking Zone to include 2 nd Street,
between Washington and Lincoln.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Hinsdale, DuPage and Cook Counties and State of Illinois, as
follows:
 
SECTION 1:   Recitals.  The foregoing recitals are incorporated into Section 1
of this Ordinance by this reference.
 
SECTION  2:   Code Amendments. Title 6 (Motor Vehicles and Traffic), Chapter 6
(Stopping, Standing and Parking), Section 4 (Limited Parking Zones) of the
Village Code of Hinsdale is hereby amended to read in its entirety as follows:
 
“6-6-4: LIMITED PARKING ZONES:
  
A.   The areas designated in schedule IX, section 6-12-9 of this title, are
hereby established and designated as “limited parking zones”. In these zones,
no person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle in any such area between the
hours specified on any day for a greater period of time than provided in said
schedule IX, section 6-12-9 of this title.
    B.   Central Business District Time Limit Parking Zone.
       1.   The Central Business District Time Limit Parking Zone shall be
regarded as the fifteen (15) striped surface parking spaces immediately to the
north of the Hinsdale Middle School Parking Deck and all on-street parking
subject to time limitations on the following streets:
Garfield between Hinsdale Avenue and First Street
First Street, between Blaine Street and Grant Street;
Washington Street, between Chicago Avenue and 2nd Street;
Hinsdale Avenue, between Garfield and Lincoln;
Hinsdale Avenue, between Lincoln and Grant-southside of the street only.
Lincoln Street between Chicago Avenue and 2nd Street.
Chicago Avenue between Washington and Lincoln.
2nd Street, between Washington and Lincoln
       2.   The Village shall post signs or legends or notices at or near
parking areas within the Central Business District Time Limit Parking Zone
indicating the maximum allowed time that parking is permitted within the Zone,
and the hours between which such maximum allowed time limitations apply. The
maximum allowed time that parking is permitted within the Zone, and the hours
between which such maximum allowed time limitations apply, shall be determined
by the Chief of Police, in consultation with the Village Manager. Prior to
expiration of the maximum amount of permitted parking time, the operator of a
vehicle parked within the Zone shall promptly remove said vehicle from the
Central Business District Time Limit Parking Zone. No person shall move said
vehicle directly to another parking space in the Central Business District Time
Limit Parking Zone, or otherwise park said vehicle for a consecutive period of
time elsewhere in the Central Business District Time Limit Parking Zone.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Chief of Police, in consultation with the
Village Manager, may erect signs establishing fifteen (15) minute parking
spaces within the Central Business District Time Limit Parking Zone, and the
use of such spaces in accordance with the fifteen (15) minute limit shall not
count against the maximum allowed time for parking within the Zone. Nothing in
this subsection shall relieve any person from the duty to obey other and more
restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or
parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times, as provided in
this chapter or as may be indicated on official signs posted by the Village.
(Ord., 6-5-1973; amd. Ord. O2022-11, 4-26-2022; Ord. O2023-11, - -2023; Ord.
O2025-07, 2-18-2025)
SECTION 3:   Repeal of Conflicting Legislation; Severability; Validity of Non-
Conflicting Legislation. All ordinances, or parts of ordinances, in conflict
with the provisions of this Ordinance, to the extent of such conflict, are
repealed. Each section, paragraph, clause and provision of this Ordinance is
separable, and if any provision is held unconstitutional or invalid for any
reason, such decision shall not affect the remainder of this Ordinance, nor any
part thereof, other than that part affected by such decision. Except as to the
Code amendments set forth above in this Ordinance, all Chapters and Sections of
the Village Code of Hinsdale shall remain in full force and effect.
 
SECTION 4:   Effective Date.  This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect
following its passage, approval, and publication in the manner provided by law.
 
PASSED this 2nd day of September, 2025.
 
AYES:                                   
 
NAYS:                                   
 
ABSENT:                                   
 
   APPROVED by me this 2nd day of September, 2025, and attested to by the
Village Clerk this same day.

ORDINANCE NO. O2025-35
 
AN ORDINANCE
AMENDING TITLE 3 (BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS) OF THE VILLAGE CODE OF
HINSDALE TO ADD A NEW CHAPTER 21 (MOTOR FUEL TAX)
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Hinsdale (the "Village") is a non-home rule
municipality, having all of the powers and authority granted to such
municipalities pursuant to Article VII, Section 7 of the Illinois Constitution
of 1970, including the right to exercise any power and perform any function
pertaining to its government and affairs; and
 
WHEREAS, the State of Illinois has previously enacted the Municipal Motor Fuel
Tax Law, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2.3 (the “Act”), which authorized municipalities in a
county with a population of over 3,000,000 to impose by ordinance a tax upon
all persons engaged in the municipality in the business of selling motor fuel
at retail for the operation of motor vehicles upon public highways, or for the
operation of recreational watercraft upon waterways. The tax was authorized to
be imposed in one cent increments at a rate not to exceed three cents ($0.03)
per gallon; and
 
WHEREAS, the Act was recently amended at Section 8-11-2.3 by Public Act 104-
0006 (the “Legislative Amendment”). Following the Legislative Amendment, a
municipality whose territory lies partially in a county with a population of
over 3,000,000 inhabitants and partially outside such a county may, in its
discretion, impose a tax on motor fuel at a rate not to exceed three cents
($0.03) per gallon in only that portion of the municipality that lies in a
county with a population of over 3,000,000 inhabitants; and
 
WHEREAS, the Village is located partially in Cook County, Illinois, a county
with a population in excess of 3,000,000, and partially outside said County,
and is therefore authorized by the recent Legislative Amendment to Section 8-
11-2.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-2.3) to impose within the
Cook County portion of the Village only, a tax on motor fuel at a rate not to
exceed three cents ($0.03) per gallon; and
 
WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village find that the below
Village Code amendments imposing a tax on motor fuel at a rate of three cents
($0.03) per gallon within the portion of the Village lying within Cook County
furthers the public health, welfare and safety, and is in the best interests of
the Village, its residents and the public.
 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE VILLAGE OF
HINSDALE, DuPAGE AND COOK COUNTIES, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS:
 
SECTION 1:   Each whereas paragraph set forth above is incorporated by
reference into this Section 1.
 
   SECTION 2:   A new Chapter 21 (Municipal Motor Fuel Tax) is added to Title 3
(Business and License Regulations) of the Village Code of Hinsdale, to read in
its entirety as follows:
“ CHAPTER 21
MUNCIPAL MOTOR FUEL TAX
 
SECTION:
 
3-21-1: Imposition Of Tax
 
3-21-2: Collection and Administration of Tax
 
3-21-3: Penalty
 
 
3-21-1: IMPOSITION OF TAX
 
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons in the Cook County portion of the
Village engaged in the business of selling motor fuel, as defined in the Motor
Fuel Tax Law (35 ILCS 505/1 et seq.), at retail for the operation of motor
vehicles upon public highways or for the operation of recreational watercraft
upon waterways. The tax is imposed at the rate of three cents ($0.03) per
gallon of motor fuel sold at retail in the Village for the purpose of use or
consumption and not for the purpose of resale.   This tax shall be in addition
to any and all other taxes and charges.
 
The imposition of this municipal motor fuel tax is in accordance with and
subject to the provisions of Section 8-11-2.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code
(65 ILCS 5/8-11-2.3), as amended, which is incorporated as though fully set
forth herein.
 
3-21-2: COLLECTION AND ADMINISTRATION OF TAX
 
The tax imposed by this Chapter, and the civil penalties that may be assessed
as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois
Department of Revenue. The Department of Revenue shall have the full power to
administer and enforce the provisions of this Chapter.
 
3-21-3: PENALTY
 
The failure to timely collect or remit all taxes due hereunder is a violation
of this code and is subject to penalty. Each failure to collect or remit the
tax imposed hereby shall constitute a separate violation. ”
 
 
   SECTION 3:    All ordinances, or parts of ordinances, in conflict with the
provisions of this Ordinance, to the extent of such conflict, are repealed.
 
SECTION 4:   Each section, paragraph, clause and provision of this Ordinance is
separable and if any provision is held unconstitutional or invalid for any
reason, such decision shall not affect the remainder of this Ordinance, nor any
part thereof, other than that part affected by such decision.
 
SECTION 5:   Except as to the Code amendments set forth above in this
Ordinance, all Chapters and Sections of the Village Code of Hinsdale, as
amended, shall remain in full force and effect.
SECTION 6:   The Village Clerk is directed to file a certified copy of this
Ordinance with the Illinois Department of Revenue on or before the first day of
October, 2025, for administration and enforcement by the Department of Revenue
as of the first day of January, 2026.
   
SECTION 7:    This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect after its
passage, approval and publication in pamphlet form as provided by law.
 
 
PASSED this 2nd day of September 2025.
 
AYES:                                
NAYS:                                
ABSENT:                                
 
   APPROVED by me this 2nd  day of September, 2025, and attested to by the
Village Clerk this same day.
 
 
               _____________________________________
               Greg Hart, Village President
ATTEST:
 
_____________________________________
Emily Tompkins, Village Clerk
 
 
 
This Ordinance was published by me in pamphlet form on the 2nd day of
 
September, 2025.

ORDINANCE NO. O2025-36
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING VARIOUS SECTIONS IN TITLE 1 (ADMINISTRATION) OF THE
VILLAGE CODE OF HINSDALE RELATIVE TO THE APPOINTMENT OF A BUDGET OFFICER AND
ADOPTION OF A BUDGET OFFICER SYSTEM AND TO MAKE OTHER CORRESPONDING CHANGES
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Hinsdale (the "Village") is a non-home rule
municipality, having all of the powers and authority granted to such
municipalities pursuant to Article VII, Section 7 of the Illinois Constitution
of 1970, including the right to exercise any power and perform any function
pertaining to its government and affairs; and
 
WHEREAS, Section 1-11-1 of the Hinsdale Village Code (the “Village Code”)
currently provides for the adoption each year by the Village President and
Board of Trustees of an appropriation ordinance; and
 
WHEREAS, Section 8-2-9.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.1)
provides that a municipality can appoint a Budget Officer and adopt a Budget
Officer system by an affirmative vote of two-thirds of the corporate
authorities. Where such a system is adopted, the adoption of an annual budget
by the Village President and Board of Trustees each year shall be in lieu of
the passage of an appropriation ordinance; and
 
   WHEREAS, Village staff, having considered the matter, has determined that
the Village can benefit from adoption of the Budget Officer system, and have
proposed that the Village President and Board of Trustees amend the Village
Code to create the office of Budget Officer and to adopt a Budget Officer
System; and
 
   WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees, based on Village staff’s
recommendations, have determined that it is in the best interests of the
Village and its residents and businesses, to amend the Village Code to create
the office of Budget Officer and to adopt a Budget Officer System, all as set
forth below.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Hinsdale, DuPage and Cook Counties and State of Illinois, as
follows:
SECTION 1:   Each whereas paragraph set forth above is incorporated by
reference into this Section 1.
 
SECTION  2:   Sections 1-11-1 (Appropriation), 1-11-2 (Tax Levy) and 1-11-3
(Indebtedness) in Title 1 (Administration), Chapter 11 (Village Finances), of
the Village Code of Hinsdale are hereby amended to read in their entirety as
follows, with additions underlined and deletions indicated using strikethrough
:
 
1-11-1: APPROPRIATIONSBUDGET OFFICER SYSTEM ADOPTED :
 
A. Adoption of Budget Officer System and Procedures. Beginning with the
preparation and adoption of a budget for the Village’s fiscal year commencing
on January 1, 2026, and for all fiscal years thereafter, the Village hereby
adopts the municipal budget officer system and procedures as set forth in
Sections 8-2-9.1 through 8-2-9.10 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-
2-9.1 - 8-2-9.10) (for purposes of this section, the “Municipal Code”), in lieu
of the passage of an annual appropriation ordinance. 
 
B. Budget Officer appointment and removal. The village president, with the
approval of the board of trustees, shall appoint a budget officer who shall
have the powers, duties and responsibilities enumerated in the Municipal Code,
as amended. The budget officer may be removed by a majority vote of the
corporate authorities.
 
C. Preparation and Passage of Budget. The budget officer shall compile a budget
pursuant to the Municipal Code, as amended, containing estimates of revenues
available to the village for the fiscal year for which the budget is drafted,
together with recommended expenditures for the village and all of the village’s
boards, commissions and departments. Said budget shall, following its
publication and the holding of a public hearing in the manner required by
Section 8-2-9.9 of the Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.9), be adopted by
corporate authorities of the village prior to the beginning of the fiscal year
to which it applies. The budget officer shall be responsible for ensuring that
the budget is timely filed with the proper government agencies as required by
state law.
 
D. Budget Amendments. The corporate authorities hereby delegate to the budget
officer such authority to amend the budget without approval of the corporate
authorities as is provided by Section 8-2-9.6 of the Municipal Code. Amendments
to budgeted amounts between departments, however, shall be additionally
approved by the Village President. Amendments requiring approval of the
corporate authorities shall be approved by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the
members of the corporate authorities then holding office. No revision
increasing the budget shall be made in the event funds are not available to
effectuate the purpose of the revision.
 
During the first quarter of each fiscal year, as required by statute, the
village president and board of trustees shall enact an appropriation ordinance
in which shall be itemized all anticipated expenditures to be met during the
coming year, other than those payable from bond issues.
 
This chapter shall be published as required by law within ten (10) days after
its enactment. (1965 Code § 9-2.01)
 
1-11-2: TAX LEVY1:
 
No sooner than ten (10) days after the publication of
the appropriation ordinance a A  tax levy ordinance shall be enacted as
required by law, levying such taxes as may be needed to meet the anticipated
expenses of the coming year, together with such taxes as may be required to
meet outstanding bond issues, or for purposes payable from special taxes
properly authorized.
 
A certified copy of the tax levy ordinance shall be filed with the county
clerks in both Cook and DuPage Counties not later than the second Tuesday in
DecemberSeptember . Such ordinance shall show the total  budgetedappropriated 
for each item and the amount of tax levied therefor. (1965 Code § 9-2.02)
 
Notes
 
1 65 ILCS 5/8-3-1 et seq.”
1-11-3: INDEBTEDNESS
 
No indebtedness shall be incurred, excepting such indebtedness as may be
payable solely from the proceeds of a duly authorized bond issue from a
designated specified source, unless there is a prior appropriation of funds in
the annual budget of the village  out of which such indebtedness could be paid,
as provided by statute. Provided, that during the first quarter of any fiscal
year, before the enactment of the current appropriation ordinance, the village
may operate under the appropriation ordinance of the preceding year.

SECTION 5: Subsections B and C of Section 1-8D-4 (Powers and Duties) in Title 1

“1-8D-4: POWER AND DUTIES:
 
The director of finance shall perform such duties and shall have such

and responsibilities shall include:
 
[…]
 
B. Reserved.To assist the village manager in preparing and presenting to the
board of trustees at the end of each fiscal year a budget estimate of revenue

C. To assist the Budget Officer village manager in preparing and presenting to
the board of trustees , before the end of each fiscal year, on or before the

containing estimates of revenues available for the ensuring fiscal year,
together with recommended expenditures for the Village and all of its funds and
departments.   an appropriation ordinance appropriating such sum or sums of
money as may be deemed necessary to defray all necessary expenses and
liabilities of the village, specifying particularly the object and purposes for
which such appropriations are made and the amount appropriated for each object
or purpose.

SECTION  6:   All ordinances, or parts of ordinances, in conflict with the
provisions of this Ordinance, to the extent of such conflict, are repealed.
 
SECTION 7:   Each section, paragraph, clause and provision of this Ordinance is
separable and if any provision is held unconstitutional or invalid for any
reason, such decision shall not affect the remainder of this Ordinance, nor any
part thereof, other than that part affected by such decision.
 
SECTION 8:   Except as to the Code provisions set forth above in this
Ordinance, all chapters and sections of the Village Code of the Village of
Hinsdale, as amended, shall remain in full force and effect.
 
SECTION 9:   This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect after its
adoption, approval and publication in pamphlet form as provided by law.

TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL VILLAGE CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Intent
1-1-3: Amendments to Code
1-1-4: Distribution of Code
1-1-1: TITLE:
This Code shall be known as the "Village Code of Hinsdale", and is hereby
authorized to be printed and published in book form. Any reference to the
number of any section contained herein shall be understood to refer to the
position of the same under its appropriate chapter heading, its article
heading, if any, and to the penalty clause relating thereto, as well as to the
section itself, when reference is made to this Code by title in any legal
document or ordinance of the Village. (1965 Code, secs. 29-1.01, 29-3.01)
1-1-2: INTENT:
All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code
shall be liberally construed in the order that the true intent of the Village
President and Board of Trustees may be fully carried out. (1965 Code, sec. 29-
1.06)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS TO CODE:
   A.   Reference to Code: Any addition or amendments to this Code, when passed
in such form as to indicate the intention of the President and Board of
Trustees to make the same a part of this Code shall be deemed to be
incorporated herein so that a reference to the Municipal Code of Hinsdale shall
be understood to include them. (1965 Code, sec. 29-2.01)
   B.   Penalties: In case of amendment of any section of this Code containing
the provisions for which a penalty is provided in another section, the penalty
so provided in such section shall be held to relate to the amended section or
the amending section without re-enacting the penalty in the amendatory
ordinance. (5-18-71)
   C.   Recording Amendments: It shall be the duty of the Village Clerk to keep
at least one copy of the Municipal Code of Hinsdale which he shall mark in the
following manner: Whenever any ordinance which amends or makes an addition to
the Code is passed and approved, he shall note on the margin of the section or
sections amended that such amendment has been made, with a reference to the
place in the amendment book, hereinafter described where the amendment may be
found, and in the case of an addition, he shall mark in the appropriate place a
notation that such addition has been made, with a similar reference to the
aforementioned amendment book where such additions may be found.
The Village Clerk shall also keep a separate book containing every amendment or
addition passed to this Code, with a reference on each copy of such amendment
or addition as to the place in the record of ordinances where the original
corresponding ordinance may be found.
The above mentioned records shall be kept in addition to the record of
ordinances which the Village Clerk is required to keep by Statute. (1965 Code,
sec. 29-2.03)
1-1-4: DISTRIBUTION OF CODE:
All of the printed copies of this Code belonging to the Village shall be
deposited with the Village Clerk. The Clerk shall deliver one copy thereof to
the President and one to each member of the Board of Trustees and copies to
such other persons as the President and Board of Trustees may direct. (1965
Code, sec. 29-3.02)
The President and Board of Trustees shall have the power to extend or
reciprocate courtesies of other municipalities by presenting them with a copy
of this Code, bound at the expense of the Village, as to them seem suitable.
(1965 Code, sec. 29-3.03)
CHAPTER 2
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Village Code Adopted
1-2-2: Code Effective Date
1-2-3: Repeal of General Ordinances
1-2-4: Publication
1-2-5: Effective Date
BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of
Hinsdale, DuPage and Cook Counties, as follows:
1-2-1: VILLAGE CODE ADOPTED:
The following Titles 1 through 12, both inclusive, are hereby ordained and
adopted as the general ordinances of the Village of Hinsdale, pursuant to
Article VII of the Constitution of the State of Illinois and pursuant to the
provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code, and said titles shall constitute the
Village Code of Hinsdale.
1-2-2: CODE EFFECTIVE DATE:
The provisions of such Code shall be in full force and effect on and after
December 1, 1981. Chapters 1 through 29 of the Municipal Code of the Village of
Hinsdale of 1965 are repealed as of December 1, 1981.
1-2-3: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
The repeal provided for in the preceding Section of this Chapter shall not
affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture
incurred or any contract or right established accruing before December 1, 1981.
The repeal provided for in the previous Section shall affect only those
ordinances contained in said 1965 Code as amended. Ordinances relating to bond
issues, contracts, conveyances, appropriation and levies, salaries and wages,
franchises, buildings, zoning, imposition of taxes and other ordinances having
been adopted independent of the Code of 1965 shall remain in full force and
effect. (11-17-81, eff. 12-1-81)
1-2-4: PUBLICATION:
This Ordinance and the Code of the Village of Hinsdale shall be published in
book form ten (10) days prior to its effective date.
1-2-5: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect as of December 1, 1981. (11-
17-81, eff. 12-1-81)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction Of Words
1-3-2: Definitions, General
1-3-3: Officers And Employees
1-3-4: Distinction Between Wholesaler And Retailer
1-3-5: Catchlines
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this Code importing the plural number is
used, in describing or referring to any matters, parties or persons, any single
matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included, although distributive
words may not have been used. When any subject matter, party or person is
referred to in any section of this Code by words importing the singular number
only, or the masculine gender, several matters, parties or persons and females
as well as males and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included. Words in
the present tense shall include the future. (1965 Code, sec. 29-1.02)
   A.   The word "person" means any individual, partnership, copartnership,
firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate,
political subdivision, State agency, or any other legal entity, or its legal
representative, agent or assigns. (6-1-1982)
   B.   The words "this Code", whenever used in this Municipal Code, shall be
held and taken to mean the entire Code, including each and every section
thereof.
   C.   The word "Village", whenever used in this Code, shall be held to mean
the "Village of Hinsdale".
   D.   The words "written" and "in writing" may include printing.
Provided, that these rules of construction shall not be applied to any section
of this Code which contains any express provisions excluding such construction
or where the subject matter or content of such section may be repugnant
thereto. (1965 Code, sec. 29-1.02)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS, GENERAL:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this Code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT:                 A person acting on behalf of another.
BOARD:                 Unless otherwise indicated, the Board of Trustees of the
                       Village.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The Village President and Board.
COUNTY:                The Counties of DuPage and Cook, State of Illinois.
FEE:                   A sum of money charged by the Village for the carrying
                       on of a business, profession or occupation.
                       In 2019, the fiscal year of the Village shall begin on
FISCAL YEAR:           May 1 and end on December 31. The 2020 fiscal year, and
                       all fiscal years thereafter, shall be from January 1
                       through December 31.
LICENSE:               The permission granted for the carrying on of a
                       business, profession or occupation.
MAYOR:                 See Village President.
                       Any offense for which a sentence to a term of
MISDEMEANOR:           imprisonment in other than a penitentiary for less than
                       one year may be imposed 1 .
                       Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and
                       welfare of the inhabitants of the Village; or any act or
NUISANCE:              thing repugnant to, or creating a hazard to, or having a
                       detrimental effect on the property of another person or
                       to the community.
                       As applied to a building or land, this term shall
OCCUPANT:              include any person who occupies the whole or any part of
                       such building or land, whether alone or with others.
                       Any act forbidden by any provision of this Code or the
OFFENSE:               omission of any act required by the provisions of this
                       Code.

                       for the City of Chicago, Illinois. All legal or official
                       proceedings of the Board of Trustees and all official

OFFICIAL TIME:         when, by ordinance, resolution or action of any officer

TENANT:                include any person who occupies the whole or any part of
                       such building or land, whether alone or with others.
                       The President of the Village may be referred to as
VILLAGE PRESIDENT:     "Mayor" or "President" of the Village. (1965 Code, sec.
                       9-8.08; amd. 1981 Code; Ord. 4-2-1996; Ord. O2019-24, 8-
                       6-2019)

1    S.H.A. 730 ILCS 5/5-1-14.
1-3-3: OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village officer or employee by
title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the
Village of Hinsdale" and shall be taken to mean the officer or employee of the
Village having the title mentioned or performing the duties indicated.
No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided in this Code for a failure to perform such duty, unless the
intention of the President and Board of Trustees to impose such a fine or
penalty on such officer or employee is specifically and clearly expressed in
the section creating the duty. (1965 Code, sec. 29-1.05)
1-3-4: DISTINCTION BETWEEN WHOLESALER AND RETAILER:
In all cases where the words "wholesaler" or "wholesale dealer" are used in
this Code, unless otherwise specifically defined, they shall be understood to
relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to
persons who purchase for the purpose of resale, as distinguished from a retail
dealer who sells in smaller quantities direct to the consumer. (1965 Code, sec.
29-1.03)
1-3-5: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this Village Code are intended as
mere catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed
or taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify
or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
division or section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or
reenacted. (1981 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Application Of Penalty
1-4-3: Village Jail
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
Whenever in this code or in any ordinance of the village any act is prohibited
or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this code
or such ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act
is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the
violation of any such provision of this code or any ordinance shall be punished
by a fine of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) and not exceeding
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). A separate offense shall be deemed to
have been committed on each day during which a violation occurs or continues.
In addition to a fine, the court may impose a period of conditional discharge
as defined in 730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1-4 or court supervision as
defined in 730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1-21 of the criminal code for a
period of up to six (6) months, an order of restitution, an order to perform
community service, an order to complete an education program and/or any other
appropriate penalties or conditions authorized in any section of this code or
ordinance or any conditions for conditional discharge set forth in 730 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/5-6-3 or for court supervision in 730 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/5-6-3.1 as the foregoing are amended from time to time. (Ord. O2012-
10, 3-6-2012)
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PENALTY:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of
this code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this code where any duty
is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any action which is of a
continuing nature is forbidden or is declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor. (1981 Code)
1-4-3: VILLAGE JAIL:
   A.   Establishment: The place in the village heretofore established and used
as the jail, or any other place which may be hereafter established by the
village board of trustees for that purpose, is hereby declared to be the
village jail. (1965 Code § 9-5.01)
   B.   Keeper: The chief of police shall be the keeper of the jail and shall
have custody over all persons confined therein and of all property pertaining
thereto. (1965 Code § 9-5.02)
   C.   Prisoners:
      1.   Incarceration: The jail shall be used for the incarceration of all
persons arrested for violating any laws of the state of Illinois, the United
States, or for violating any village ordinance until such person shall be
lawfully brought before a judge for hearing or until such person shall be
lawfully transferred to some other place of incarceration or otherwise lawfully
released. (1965 Code § 9-5.03)
      2.   Escape: It shall be unlawful for any person to escape or attempt to
escape or to assist any prisoner to escape or attempt to escape from jail.
(1965 Code § 9-5.04)
      3.   Communication With Prisoners: It shall be unlawful for any person to
communicate with any prisoner held in the jail without the permission of the
chief of police or the police officer in charge. (1965 Code § 9-5.05)
CHAPTER 5
VILLAGE PRESIDENT
SECTION:
1-5-1: Election; Term Of Office
1-5-2: Oath; No Salary
1-5-3: Duties, General
1-5-4: President Pro Tem
1-5-1: ELECTION; TERM OF OFFICE:
The village president shall be elected for a term of four (4) years, and he
shall be the president of the board of trustees, as is provided by statute.
(1965 Code, sec. 1-1.01)
1-5-2: OATH; NO SALARY:
Before entering into the duties of the office, the president shall take the
oath of office as prescribed by statute. The president shall not receive any
salary or other compensation for the performance of the duties of president.
(Ord. O2002-27, 5-7-2002)
1-5-3: DUTIES, GENERAL:
The village president shall be the chief executive officer of the village, and
he shall perform all such duties as may be required of him by statute or
ordinance.
   A.   He shall have supervision over all of the employees of the village.
   B.   He shall have the power and authority to inspect at any reasonable time
all books and records kept by any village officer or employee. (1965 Code, sec.
1-1.02)
   C.   Whenever there is a question as to the respective powers or duties of
any appointed officer of the village, this shall be settled by the president
and he shall have the power to delegate to any such officer any duty which is
to be performed when no specific officer has been directed to perform the duty.
(1965 Code, sec. 1-1.03)
   D.   He may remove any appointed member of a commission, board or ad hoc
committee of the village on any formal charge, whenever he is of the opinion
that the interests of the village demand the removal, but he shall report the
reasons for the removal to the village board at a meeting to be held not less
than five (5) nor more than ten (10) days after the removal. If the village
president fails or refuses to report to the village board the reasons for the
removal, or if the village board by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of all its members
authorized by law to be elected, disapproves of the removal, the member
thereupon shall be restored to the office from which he was removed. The vote
shall be by ayes and nays, which shall be entered upon the journal of the
village board. This section shall not apply to members of boards, commissions
and ad hoc committees as to which removal is covered by statutes of the state
of Illinois. (Ord., 10-16-1973)
1-5-4: PRESIDENT PRO TEM:
During the temporary absence or disability of the village president, the board
of trustees shall elect one of its members to act as president pro tem, who
during the absence or disability of the president shall perform the duties
pertaining to the office. (1965 Code, sec. 1-1.05)
CHAPTER 6
VILLAGE BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Election; Functions
1-6-2: Oath; Salary
1-6-3: President Of The Board; Vote
1-6-4: Committees Of The Board
1-6-5: Meetings Of The Board
1-6-5-1: Electronic Attendance
1-6-5-2: Sample Format For Electronic Attendance Request
1-6-6: Rules Of Order
1-6-7: Ordinances; Approval, Veto
1-6-1: ELECTION; FUNCTIONS 1 :
The members of the board of trustees, consisting of six (6) persons, shall be
elected to office for four (4) year terms, according to the method provided by
statute. This board shall be the legislative department of the village
government, and shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be
delegated by statute to it. (1965 Code § 2-1.01)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/5-2-15.
1-6-2: OATH; SALARY:
The members of the board of trustees shall take the oath of office prescribed
by statute. Said members shall receive no salaries for the performance of their
duties as trustees. (1965 Code § 2-1.02)
1-6-3: PRESIDENT OF THE BOARD; VOTE:
The village president shall be the presiding officer of all regular and special
meetings of the board of trustees.
The village president shall not vote on any ordinance, resolution or motion,
except: a) where the vote of the trustees has resulted in a tie; b) where one-
half (½) of the trustees have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or
motion even though there is no tie vote; or c) where a vote greater than a
majority of the corporate authorities is required by the Illinois municipal
code to adopt an ordinance, resolution or motion. Nothing in this section shall
deprive an acting president, chairman pro tem or a president pro tem from
voting in his capacity as trustee. (Ord., 12-7-1982; amd. Ord. O2021-23, 8-10-
2021)
1-6-4: COMMITTEES OF THE BOARD:
   A.   Standing Committees: The standing committees of the board of trustees
shall be appointed by the president, shall consist of four (4) members each,
one of whom shall be appointed by the president as chairman, and shall be
appointed on each of the following matters:
      Administration and community affairs
      Environment and public services
      Zoning and public safety
   B.   Special Committees: All special committees shall also be appointed by
the president with the consent of the board of trustees.
   C.   Meetings Of Standing Committees: Standing committees shall only meet
upon the direction of the board of trustees.
   D.   Committee of the Whole: the committee of the whole is comprised of the
board of trustees, absent the village president. The committee of the whole
shall meet on an as-needed basis. (Ord. O2015-01, 1-20-2015; amd. Ord. O2021-
23, 8-10-2021 )
1-6-5: MEETINGS OF THE BOARD:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The board of trustees shall hold its regular meetings
on the first and third Tuesday of each month at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M., and
no notice of such regular meetings shall be required; provided, however, that
if the meeting date shall fall on a legal holiday, the board of trustees shall
meet on the day following. Unless otherwise provided for, the meetings of the
board of trustees shall be held in the Memorial Building.
   B.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called by the village
president or any three (3) trustees upon at least twenty four (24) hours'
notice to all members and the president; provided, that if all of the trustees
are present at a special meeting, no notice of such meeting shall be necessary
and such notice shall be deemed waived. Meeting calls shall be in writing, duly
signed and shall be presented to the village clerk, who shall proceed
immediately to prepare notices of such meeting and shall cause them to be
served on the president and members of the board of trustees personally, or by
mail; such notices shall describe in brief the nature or objects of the special
meeting.
   C.   Meetings Open To The Public: All regular or special meetings of the
board of trustees shall be open to the public.
   D.   Quorum: A majority of the trustees or three (3) trustees and the
village president shall constitute a quorum of the board of trustees.
   E.   Disturbing Meetings: It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any
meeting of the board of trustees or of any committee thereof; any person
violating the provisions of this subsection shall be fined not less than five
dollars ($5.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
   F.   No Smoking: It shall be unlawful to smoke at any meeting of the board
of trustees or any meeting of any committee, commission or board of the
village. (1965 Code §§ 2-1.03, 2-1.09, 2-2.02, 2-2.03; amd. Ord., 5-1-1984;
Ord. O2021-38, 12-14-2021)
1-6-5-1: ELECTRONIC ATTENDANCE:
   A.   A quorum of trustees must be physically present at the location of an
open or closed meeting of the board of trustees.
   B.   Minutes of all meetings shall reflect if a trustee was physically
present or present by means of a video or audio conference. Lack of such a
specification shall be deemed to indicate that the trustee in question was
physically present.
   C.   As provided herein, trustees who are not physically present may
participate in open or closed meetings by means of a video or audio conference.
Such electronic participation may only occur if the trustee is prevented from
physically attending by: 1) personal illness or disability; 2) employment
purposes; 3) business of the public body; 4) a family emergency; or 5) another
emergency. If a trustee wishes to attend a meeting electronically, the trustee
must notify the village clerk at least forty eight (48) hours before the
meeting, unless advance notice is impractical. Notification may be in person or
in writing, or by phone, e-mail or facsimile transmission. The notification
shall include a detailed recitation of the particular circumstances why the
trustee cannot attend, and also cite one of the five (5) above specified
categories. The notification also shall substantially follow the format laid
out in section
1-6-5-2 of this chapter. For purposes of this rule, the deputy village clerk
shall be considered, and is hereby designated, as the agent of the village
clerk. Notice given to the village clerk or deputy village clerk shall be
sufficient. Copies of the request shall be provided to all trustees promptly,
but in no event later than the meeting in question.
   D.   Upon receipt of notice of intent to participate electronically, the
village clerk, deputy village clerk or his/her designees shall make appropriate
arrangements for the trustee to participate electronically, such as by
arranging a speakerphone for the meeting room and obtaining contact
information. The equipment shall provide output sufficient for persons
attending the meeting, and members of the audience, to hear the trustee speak,
and also shall allow the trustee to hear other trustees and any person who
addresses the board of trustees.
   E.   The board of trustees allows electronic attendance for qualifying
reasons listed in the Illinois open meetings act, as a matter of policy. The
audio or video equipment shall be activated at the beginning of the meeting, or
at the time requested by the trustee, so that the trustee can participate.
   F.   If the trustee who is attending electronically would normally chair the
meeting, a president pro tempore who is physically present may be appointed.
   G.   When a trustee attends a meeting electronically, all votes shall be by
roll call vote. An electronically attending trustee must identify himself or
herself by name and be recognized by the president before speaking.
   H.   An approved request to participate electronically shall entitle the
trustee involved to attend at the subject meeting and any closed sessions
called during that meeting.
   I.   This section shall apply in like manner to any subsidiary committee,
subcommittee or other agency of the village that is a "public body" under the
Illinois open meetings act. (Ord. O2006-72, 10-3-2006)

and reachable at the following phone number:

   OR
