7-2-9: Landmark Tree Preservation Plan
7-2-10: Tree Board
7-2-11: General Penalty
7-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings hereafter
ascribed to them:
LANDMARK TREE: Any tree that is eight inches (8") in diameter or more measured
at four and one-half feet (41/2') above ground level on the high side of the
tree.
PUBLIC TREE: Any tree located on right of way, parkway or property of the
village of Hinsdale or any other public place, or any other tree owned by the
village of Hinsdale.
REMOVE OR REMOVAL: The physical detachment or elimination of a tree, or the
effective detachment or elimination of a tree, through damage or otherwise.
Without limitation of the foregoing, "remove" or "removal" does not include the
pruning of trees.
TREE: A self-supporting, woody plant, together with its root system, having a
well defined stem or trunk or multistemmed trunk system, and more or less well
defined crown, and a mature height of at least eight feet (8'). "Tree" shall
not include trees in containers or nursery stock trees maintained for resale.
(Ord. O2011-08, 2-15-2011)
7-2-2: PLANTING AND REMOVAL:
   A.   Permit To Plant: It shall be unlawful to plant any tree or shrub in any
public street or parkway or other public place without having first secured a
permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the director of
public services or the village forester, who shall be authorized to issue such
permits. All trees and shrubs so planted shall be placed subject to the
directions of the director of public services or the village forester.
Provided, however, that no permit shall be issued for the planting of any
willow, cottonwood, box elder, catalpa or any variety of poplar trees.
   B.   Work On Public Trees:
      1.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to remove, cut down or
otherwise work on any tree or shrub in any public street or parkway or other
public place without having first secured a permit from the village.
Applications for such permits shall be made to the director of public services
or the village forester, who shall have authority to issue such permits for
good cause shown. The director of public services or the village forester may,
at his or her discretion, seek a recommendation on the issuance of a permit
hereunder from the tree board (as established under section
7-2-10 of this chapter). Except as set forth below, a fee of five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00) shall be paid to the village for any permit issued
hereunder to remove or cut down any tree in any public street or parkway.
However, the fee for issuance of a permit to remove or cut down a tree under
this section shall be increased to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) if the
owner of any property for which a building permit has been issued applies for a
permit hereunder after the issuance of the building permit.
      2.   Permit To Move A Public Tree: No fee hereunder shall apply for a
permit issued to move a tree on any public street or parkway to another
location on a public street or parkway (said location to be determined by the
director of public services or the village forester); provided, however, that
any permit to move such a tree shall provide that if, within a time specified
by the director of public services or the village forester (not to exceed 36
months) from the date of the issuance of the permit, the tree dies then the
five thousand dollar ($5,000.00) fee designated under subsection B1 of this
section shall apply and be paid to the Village. Death of a tree shall be
determined at the sole discretion of the Director of Public Services or the
Village Forester.
      3.   Work Without A Permit: Any person who removes or cuts down any tree
in any public street or parkway or other public place without a permit from the
Village, or causes the death of a tree in any public street or parkway or other
public place by negligence or failure to adequately protect said tree during
construction on that person's property, shall pay the Village a permit fee of
twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00).
      4.   Diseased Or Damaged Trees; Health Of Surrounding Trees: The fees set
forth under this provision regarding permits for the removal or moving of trees
and removal of trees without a permit shall not apply if in the opinion of the
Director of Public Services or the Village Forester the tree should be removed:
a) due to disease or damage unrelated to any construction on the property; or
b) if removal of the tree due to its location, condition or other factors would
benefit the health and/or viability of surrounding trees.
      5.   Forestry Goals: The Director of Public Services or the Village
Forester may, at his or her discretion, seek a recommendation from the Tree
Board on a waiver of the permit fees set forth under this provision for the
removal and/or replacement of a tree on public property, if in the opinion of
the Director of Public Services or the Village Forester the location and/or
mature height, width or form of the tree on public property negatively impacts
surrounding trees on public property and/or would not promote the development
of a full and healthy street corridor as set forth in the Village's "Community
Forestry Manual of Policy and Procedures". Replacement of the tree may be
required at the discretion of the Tree Board and such replacement as to
location and species shall be in accordance with the aforementioned Village
Manual of Policy and Procedures.
      6.   Commercial Development: The fees set forth under this provision
regarding permits for the removal or moving of trees and removal of trees
without a permit shall not apply if the removal or moving of said tree(s) is
pursuant to a landscape plan approved by the Board of Trustees as part of a
commercial development.
      7.   Public Tree Appeals: An appeal from the decision of the Director of
Public Services or the Village Forester regarding a permit under this section
or the imposition of a related fee may be taken to the Tree Board by the person
or entity aggrieved by said decision, any such appeal to be taken within sixty
(60) days of the date of the decision. The decision of the Tree Board in the
case of an appeal shall be final.
      8.   Work On Public And Private Trees: Any person doing tree work on elm
or ash trees on either public or private property in the Village is required to
sanitize their equipment by cleaning all pruning and cutting tools with rubbing
alcohol between uses so as to prevent the spread of disease or fungus. (Ord.
O2016-16, 3-17-2016)
      9.   Tree Fund: All fees collected pursuant to this provision shall be
placed in a Tree Fund, the proceeds of which shall be used only for the
replacement of trees on public property or for the maintenance or treatment of
trees on public property or, with the consent of the Tree Board, for
educational or informational programming or materials pertaining directly to
trees on public property, including information regarding the varieties of
trees, as well as their maintenance and preservation. (Ord. O2017-06, 3-7-2017)
7-2-3: RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Advertisements And Notices: It shall be unlawful to attach any sign,
address plate, advertisement or notice to any tree or shrub in any street,
parkway or other public place.
   B.   Wires: It shall be unlawful to attach any wire or other rope to any
tree on public property without permission of the Village President and Board
of Trustees.
Any person given the rights to maintain poles and wires in the streets, alleys
or other public places in the Village shall, in the absence of provision in the
franchise concerning the subject, keep such wires and poles from and away from
any trees or shrubs in such places so far as may be possible and shall keep all
such trees and shrubs properly trimmed and subject to the supervision of the
Director of Public Services, so that no injury shall be done to the poles or
wires or shrubs and trees by contact.
   C.   Gas Pipes: Any person maintaining any gas pipe in the Village shall, in
the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such
pipes free from leaks.
   D.   Excavations: In making excavations in streets or other public places
proper care shall be taken to avoid injury to the roots of any tree or shrub,
wherever possible. (Ord. O2011-08, 2-15-2011)
7-2-4: DANGEROUS TREES:
Any tree or shrub, which overhangs any sidewalk, street or other public place
in the village in such a way as to impede or interfere with traffic, or travel,
or obstruct the view on such public place shall be trimmed by the owner of the
abutting premises on which such tree or shrub grows so that the obstruction
shall cease.
If, after ten (10) days' notice by registered mail, the owner fails to remove
obstructing or hazardous limbs, the director of public services is authorized
hereby to take such steps as are necessary to ensure elimination of the
obstruction or hazard to public safety and to bill the property owner for the
expense incurred thereby. (Ord. O2011-08, 2-15-2011)
7-2-5: INJURY TO TREES AND SHRUBS:
It shall be unlawful to injure any tree or shrub planted in any such public
place.
No tree climbing spikes will be used on public trees unless the permit for the
work certifies that the tree involved is dead. (Ord. O2011-08, 2-15-2011)
7-2-6: AIR SPACE AROUND TREES PROTECTED:
No person shall, without the written permission of the director of public
services, place or maintain upon the grounds within the lines of any street,
parkway or other public place within the village, stone, cement or other
substance which shall impede the free passage of air to the roots of any tree
located within the lines of such street, parkway or other public place, without
leaving an open space of ground outside of the trunk of such tree in an area
not less than four feet (4') square. (Ord. O2011-08, 2-15-2011)
7-2-7: TREES PROTECTED:
During the period in which the erection or repair of any building is being
made, the owner thereof shall place such guards around all nearby trees
standing within the lines of any street, parkway or other public place as shall
effectively prevent injury to such trees in accordance with the village's
designing for mandatory tree protection during construction policy, as amended.
(Ord. O2011-08, 2-15-2011)
7-2-8: LANDMARK TREE REMOVAL ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
The village shall be provided with fourteen (14) days' prior written notice by
any person who proposes to remove a landmark tree located on private property
within the village, including, but not limited to, as part of any applicable
village construction permit application. Said notice shall be provided to the
director of public services in a form to be determined by the village. (Ord.
O2011-08, 2-15-2011)
7-2-9: LANDMARK TREE PRESERVATION PLAN:
Any permit applicant pursuant to title 9, "Building Regulations", of this code
who proposes to demolish a principal structure or a detached garage or includes
construction that will add six hundred (600) square feet or more of gross floor
area to a principal structure or a detached garage, shall include a landmark
tree preservation plan as part of the application. The tree preservation plan
shall include a site plan of the property of a scale not less than one inch
equals twenty feet (1" = 20'), which plan shall be graphically and accurately
marked with all of the following information:
   A.   The street address or legal description of the property and all
property lines of the property;
   B.   The location of all buildings, structures, driveways, walkways, and
parking areas on the property;
   C.   The proposed location of all temporary storage areas during
construction on the property;
   D.   The location of utility service lines on the property;
   E.   The location of all landmark trees on the property and within fifteen
feet (15') of any property line of the property (collectively the "protected
trees");
   F.   A legend stating the diameter of the landmark tree, genus and species,
and general condition of each protected tree;
   G.   The root protection zones within the property of all landmark trees;
   H.   A detailed proposal for protection of all landmark trees and for
protection of all trees other than landmark trees that may be damaged or
removed during the proposed construction activity, including, without
limitation, such measures as pruning, root pruning, use of retaining walls or
protective fencing, augering of utility lines (to improve tree survivability),
and similar measures;
   I.   A clear delineation of the perimeters of each construction activity
area and each root protection area; and
   J.   A certification from an arborist that the tree preservation plan
incorporates all reasonable steps necessary to minimize damage to trees on
property adjacent to the property. (Ord. O2011-08, 2-15-2011)
7-2-10: TREE BOARD:
   A.   Creation And Purpose: There is hereby created and established a village
tree board. The tree board shall advise and assist the president and board of
trustees with regard to those matters relative to residents and their trees in
accordance with the powers and duties set forth in this section.
   B.   Members And Terms:
      1.   Appointments: The tree board shall consist of four (4) voting
members. All members shall serve without compensation and shall be current
members of the village board of trustees. All members shall be appointed by the
village president, annually, at the first meeting in May, after the
installation of any new trustees, should it be an election year. The first tree
board established shall consist of existing members of the village board and
the chairperson shall be the current chair of the environment and public
services committee.
      2.   Terms Generally: Except as provided in subsection B3 of this
section, each appointment of a member shall be for a term of one year or until
that member's replacement has been appointed.
      3.   Chairperson: The village president, with the advice and consent of
the board of trustees, shall appoint one trustee as chairperson and one trustee
as vice chairperson. The chairperson, or the vice chairperson in the absence of
the chairperson, shall preside at all meetings and shall fulfill the customary
functions of the position of chairperson. The chairperson and vice chairperson
shall serve in that position until the expiration of their term or until the
village president has made a new appointment to those positions, whichever is
sooner.
   C.   Duties And Responsibilities: It shall be the responsibility of the tree
board to study, investigate, develop, update and administer a comprehensive
plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or
disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets, and in other public
areas. The tree board, when requested by the village board of trustees shall
consider, investigate, make finding, report and recommend upon any special
matter coming within the scope of its work. The decision of the tree board is
considered final and binding. The tree board may assign specific duties and
delegate responsibility and authority for day to day operation and activities
to the village tree crew through the director of public services. (Ord. O2015-
12, 4-21-2015)
7-2-11: GENERAL PENALTY:
Unless a more specific fine or permit provision from this chapter applies, any
person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be
punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense. Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall occur or
continue shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. O2016-16, 3-17-2016)
CHAPTER 3
PUBLIC PARKS
SECTION:
7-3-1: Hours Of Operation
7-3-2: Authorization Of Park Usage
7-3-3: Golf And Archery Prohibited
7-3-4: Fires Prohibited
7-3-5: Banner Approvals
7-3-6: Penalty
7-3-1: HOURS OF OPERATION:
Public parks within the village shall be open for use between the hours of five
o'clock (5:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M., with the exception of the
paddle tennis courts and paddle tennis hut located at Katherine Legge Memorial
park which shall be open for use until ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. from
October 1 through April 30. The hours of operation of public parks for programs
or events sponsored or approved by the village, or for which a village permit
has been issued, may be extended for any such program or event for a period of
sixty (60) minutes following the conclusion of such program or event. Signs
stating park hours shall be posted prominently in each park. (Ord. O2008-20, 5-
6-2008)
7-3-2: AUTHORIZATION OF PARK USAGE:
The village manager may authorize usage of all village of Hinsdale public parks
for nonprofit recreational purposes for a period not to exceed twenty four (24)
hours. (Ord. O2008-20, 5-6-2008)
7-3-3: GOLF AND ARCHERY PROHIBITED:
No person shall play or practice golf or archery in any village park unless
such play or practice is under the direct supervision of the director of parks
and recreation. (Ord. O2008-20, 5-6-2008)
7-3-4: FIRES PROHIBITED:
Except in a structure or stove designed for cooking or warming purposes no
person shall light or build a fire in any village park unless such fire is lit
or built under the direct supervision of the director of parks and recreation.
(Ord. O2008-20, 5-6-2008)
7-3-5: BANNER APPROVALS:
The village manager may authorize the approval of banner requests following the
requirements listed in the village of Hinsdale banner placement policy. (Ord.
O2007-48, 7-17-2007)
7-3-6: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be
punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense; provided, however, that if service
of summons is made by certified mail pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/1-2-9.1, then the maximum fine shall not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00)
for each offense. Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall
occur or continue shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. O2008-20, 5-6-
2008)
CHAPTER 4
WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM
ARTICLE A. COMBINED SYSTEM
SECTION:
7-4A-1: Combination Of Systems
7-4A-2: Properties Of System
7-4A-3: Operation Of System
7-4A-4: Disposition Of Revenues
7-4A-1: COMBINATION OF SYSTEMS:
It is hereby found, determined and declared necessary for the best interests of
the village that the existing waterworks system of the village and the existing
sanitary sewerage system of the village be combined into a single utility to be
known and designated as the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the
village, pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-39-1 et seq. (Ord., 8-
2-1966)
7-4A-2: PROPERTIES OF SYSTEM:
All property, real, personal and mixed, comprising the now existing waterworks
system and sanitary sewerage system of the village is hereby found, determined
and declared to constitute the properties of the combined waterworks and
sewerage system of the village. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4A-3: OPERATION OF SYSTEM:
From and after the effective date hereof said waterworks system and said
sanitary sewerage system shall be owned and operated by the village as a
combined utility, known as the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the
village, and all improvements and extensions to said waterworks and sewerage
system, either or both, shall be considered as improvements and extensions to
said combined utility; and all the properties, assets, obligations and
liabilities, of all kinds, of said waterworks system and of said sanitary
sewerage system, existing, outstanding and accruing or to accrue, shall be
held, used and acknowledged as the properties, assets, obligations and
liabilities of said combined utility. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4A-4: DISPOSITION OF REVENUES:
All revenues derived from the combined waterworks and sewerage system shall be
held by the village treasurer separate and apart from all other funds of the
village and shall be deposited in the waterworks and sewerage fund promptly
upon receipt of same. Said funds shall be administered and disbursed in
accordance with a separate ordinance. In the event of any conflict between the
provisions of said ordinance and this chapter, said ordinance shall control.
(Ord., 8-2-1966)
ARTICLE B. WATER AND SEWER RATES
SECTION:
7-4B-1: Sewer Rates
7-4B-2: Water Rates
7-4B-3: Collection Of Water Charges
7-4B-4: Lien For Delinquent Charges
7-4B-5: Discontinuation Of Water Service; Charges
7-4B-6: Meter Testing In The Case Of Contested Bills
7-4B-7: Water And Sewer System Infrastructure Maintenance Fee
7-4B-1: SEWER RATES:
   A.   Authorization: Pursuant to division 139 or article 11 of the Illinois
municipal code, the following separate sewer rates are hereby established:
The sewer service charge is hereby established at an amount equivalent to
fifteen percent (15%) of the water bill of each customer. (Ord., 12-7-1982)
   B.   Applicability Of Charge: Customers subject to this charge shall include
all users of water supplied by the combination waterworks and sewerage system
of the village, except customers whose sewers are connected directly to sewers
owned, operated and maintained by the Hinsdale sanitary district. (Ord., 8-2-
1966)
7-4B-2: WATER RATES:
Water Rates: The following rates shall be paid for water service for meter
readings billed on or after July 1, 2024, and thereafter as follows:
   A.   Water Customers Located Within the Village:
      1.   $8.99 rate for each 100 cubic feet up to 10,000 cubic feet per two-
month billing cycle; and
      2.   $13.90 rate for each 100 cubic feet over 10,000 cubic feet per two-
month billing cycle.
   B.   Water Customers Not Located Within The Village: Water customers not
located within the corporate limits of the village of Hinsdale shall pay
a$11.57 rate for each 100 cubic feet up to 10,000 cubic feet, and a$13.90 rate
for each 100 cubic feet over 10,000 cubic feet per two-month billing cycle.
   C.   Large Water Customers: A water customer whose aggregate annual water
usage exceeds two million (2,000,000) cubic feet for all accounts in said
customer’s name shall be subject to a rate of$16.17 per 100 cubic feet per two-
month billing cycle.
   D.   Minimum charge: none.
   E.   Late Payment Penalty: any bill which remains unpaid after the due date
stated on the water bill, which is approximately thirty (30) days after the
date of mailing, shall be considered delinquent, and a penalty of five percent
(5%) of the unpaid balance shall be added.
   F.   Utility Tax: The charges above include the five percent (5%) village
utility tax. (Ord. O2021-25, 8-10-2021; amd. Ord. O2022-24, 9-6-2022; Ord.
O2023-24, - -2023; Ord. O2024-12,  6-11-2024)
7-4B-3: COLLECTION OF WATER CHARGES:
Charges for water shall commence on the date when the water is turned on in
accordance with the written application for water service and shall continue
until notice is received by the village to discontinue water service, and a
final meter reading is taken.
In the event of a change in ownership of premises receiving water service or a
change in the tenancy of the premises where the new tenant is to be charged for
water service, the new owner or tenant shall be obligated to ascertain from the
village the water and sewer charges due to the village prior to executing a
lease or closing a sale. Any amounts not paid by the prior tenant or owner
prior to the execution of the lease or prior to the closing of the sale shall
become the obligation of the new tenant or owner and the village shall not be
obligated to sell water to the premises until the prior charges are paid.
All water furnished shall be charged and paid for as measured and registered by
meters, and the amount so charged shall be billed and become due and payable in
bimonthly installments. If a due date falls on a Sunday or on a legal holiday
on which the village office is closed, then the due date shall be extended to
the next following business day on which the village office is open. Any
applicable discount will be allowed on a remittance made by mail if said
remittance bears a postmark dated prior to twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight of
the due date.
If more than one unit in a multiple-family building is connected to a single
meter, then the total water usage for the combined units shall be divided by
the number of units and the charge for water will be made on a per unit basis
on the assumption that each unit consumed its proportionate share of the water.
The minimum charge per unit shall be based on the minimum charge applicable to
a five-eighths inch (5/8") meter size. (Ord. O2003-10, 4-15-2003)
7-4B-4: LIEN FOR DELINQUENT CHARGES 1 :
Whenever a bill for water or sewer service remains unpaid for two (2) months
after it has been rendered, or in the event the village receives notice from
any source that premises are about to be sold, all charges for water shall be
deemed delinquent as to said premises. The village clerk shall thereupon file
with the recorder of deeds of the county in which the property is located a
lien claim in accordance with 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-139-8. Said
lien shall be foreclosed in the manner provided in said statute. (Ord., 9-20-
1984)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 7-4F-6 of this chapter.
7-4B-5: DISCONTINUATION OF WATER SERVICE; CHARGES:
   A.   Discontinuation Of Service: If payment of any water bill is not
received by the village within fifteen (15) days after the due date specified
on such bill, or if a water service customer has failed to comply with any
provision of this code pertaining to the provision of water service, then the
director of finance shall mail notice to the delinquent customer that water
service to such customer shall be discontinued unless said payment is made or
compliance with this code is completed within ten (10) days after the date of
mailing said notice. Said notice shall provide that such customer request a
meeting at which such customer may present evidence regarding whether water
service should be discontinued. Such meeting if requested, must be held prior
to the scheduled water shutoff date. If no such meeting is requested or if no
good cause is established at such meeting why water service should not be shut
off, then the village shall discontinue water service to the delinquent
customer immediately and until said payment of the charges established in
subsection B of this section are paid or compliance with this code is
completed. (Ord. O2003-10, 4-15-2003)
   B.   Charges For Renewal Of Service: The following charges for renewal of
water service shall be due and payable immediately after the decision of the
director of finance that the water service shall be discontinued, regardless of
whether the water service actually was shut off by the village:
      1.   Renewal requests from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to three thirty
o'clock (3:30) P.M.: Fifty dollars ($50.00); and
      2.   Renewal requests between three thirty o'clock (3:30) P.M. and seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M.: One hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. O2008-26, 6-3-2008)
7-4B-6: METER TESTING IN THE CASE OF CONTESTED BILLS:
In cases of a contested bill, the customer may request that the meter be tested
for accuracy. No charge will be made for the test if it is found that the meter
needs repair through normal use. If the meter is found to be accurate within
two percent (2%), the customer shall be required to reimburse the village for
the cost of the test. (Ord. O2014-43, 12-16-2014)
7-4B-7: WATER AND SEWER SYSTEM INFRASTRUCTURE MAINTENANCE FEE:
Water and Sewer System Infrastructure Maintenance Fee: A water and sewer system
infrastructure maintenance fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be imposed for
each two-month billing cycle, in addition to the rates otherwise specified
herein, and regardless of the amount of water consumed on the premises. (Ord.
O2021-25, 8-10-2021)
ARTICLE C. SEWERS; GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
7-4C-1: Manual Of Procedures For Issuance Of Sewer Permits Adopted
7-4C-2: Permit Required
7-4C-3: Installation, Repair And Maintenance Costs
7-4C-4: Street Openings
7-4C-5: Garage Drainage
7-4C-6: Prohibited Substances; Injury
7-4C-7: Rainwater Drains
7-4C-8: Cross-Connections; Separation Of Storm Inflows
7-4C-9: Protection Of Wells
7-4C-10: Penalty
7-4C-1: MANUAL OF PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF SEWER PERMITS ADOPTED:
The manual of procedures for the issuance of sewer permits of the metropolitan
sanitary district of Chicago is hereby adopted. Three (3) copies of this manual
are on file in the office of the village clerk. (Ord., 6-29-1971)
7-4C-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to make any connections with any village sewer without
having first obtained a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be
made to the village clerk and shall be accompanied by a statement as to the
purpose of such connection, the premises to be served and the specification of
such pipe to be connected and the drain from house to sewer pipe. Such
applications shall be referred to the plumbing inspector; and no such permit
shall be issued unless he shall have found that the ordinances of the village
would be complied with by making of such connections. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4C-3: INSTALLATION, REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE COSTS:
The owner of any premises in the village served by a connection with the
village sewer system shall install, maintain, repair and when necessary replace
the house sewer service line from its connection with the village sewer system
to the building it serves, at his expense. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4C-4: STREET OPENINGS 1 :
The provisions of chapter 1, article B of this title relating to excavations in
streets shall be complied with in making excavations in streets or other public
places for sewer connections. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 7-1-6F and sections 7-1B-2, 7-1B-5, and 7-1C-6 of this
  title.
7-4C-5: GARAGE DRAINAGE:
Floor drains in garages shall be connected with the storm sewer system; such
drains shall have intercepting mud or grease traps adequate to prevent the flow
of mud or greases into the sewer system. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4C-6: PROHIBITED SUBSTANCES; INJURY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any gasoline, benzine or other
volatile liquid to flow into any public sewer in the village; or to permit any
material which might injure any part of the sanitary sewer system to flow into
it. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4C-7: RAINWATER DRAINS:
It shall be unlawful to construct or permit the construction of any storm water
drain which discharges water onto any sidewalk in the village, and it shall be
unlawful to construct or permit the maintenance of any such drain which
discharges into any public street or alley at a height greater than eighteen
inches (18") above the ground or pavement. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4C-8: CROSS-CONNECTIONS; SEPARATION OF STORM INFLOWS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to permit any sanitary sewage to flow into any
storm sewer or any storm sewer to flow into any sanitary sewer.
   B.   Inflow sources of storm water to the combined sanitary and storm sewer
system shall be connected to a storm sewer within a reasonable amount of time
if a storm sewer becomes available. (Ord. O2001-14, 3-6-2001)
7-4C-9: PROTECTION OF WELLS:
It shall be unlawful to install any public or private sanitary sewer, or
combined sanitary and storm sewer or drain of any character, in the village
within the boundaries of a circle which is one hundred feet (100') in diameter
and where the center of said one hundred foot (100') circle is identical with
the center of any water well furnishing water for the municipal water supply of
the village, except that any such sanitary sewer or drain may be installed
within the boundaries of said circle if the portion within the circle is
constructed of cast-iron pipe with watertight joints tested to one hundred
(100) pounds per square inch pressure without leakage except that in no event
shall any sewer or drain be installed closer than ten feet (10') to any
municipal water well, regardless of type of construction. Any such sewer or
drain line installed within the boundaries of said circle shall be inspected
and approved both as to installation methods and pressure test by the plumbing
inspector before the same can be covered and placed in service. (Ord., 8-2-
1966)
7-4C-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than
five dollars ($5.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
ARTICLE D. SEWER SERVICE CONNECTIONS OUTSIDE VILLAGE LIMITS
SECTION:
7-4D-1: Connections and Extensions Outside Village Limits
7-4D-2: Conditions of Connection or Extension
7-4D-3: Village Water Services Required
7-4D-4: Outside Sewers Property of Village
7-4D-5: Maintenance of Outside Sewers
7-4D-6: Lateral Connections
7-4D-7: Requirements for Outside Main Extension
7-4D-8: Storm Water Prohibited
7-4D-1: CONNECTIONS AND EXTENSIONS OUTSIDE VILLAGE LIMITS:
   A.   Connections: Permission is hereby granted to any property outside the
Village limits to connect to and be serviced by the Hinsdale sanitary sewer
system, provided said property is located within either the Hinsdale sanitary
district or the sanitary district of Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater
Chicago, and provided further, that the owner of said property complies with
all the requirements and regulations of this Chapter.
   B.   Extensions: Upon presentation of a petition requesting same, the Board
of Trustees of the Village may, in their discretion, grant permission for the
extension of any sanitary sewer main of the Village beyond the corporate limits
of the Village for the purpose of serving property outside the Village limits
but located within either the Hinsdale sanitary district or the Metropolitan
Sanitary District of Greater Chicago. In the event any such extension or
portion thereof is located in a street that forms a boundary of the Village,
the property inside the Village limits abutting or having frontage on said
boundary street shall have the right to connect to said sewer extension under
the same conditions as other property inside the Village can connect to any
Village sewer. Any such sewer extension to serve outside property shall be
installed at no expense to the Village and shall be installed only after
adequate easements covering the installation are secured, and in compliance
with all provisions of this Chapter before connection to the Village sewer
system shall be permitted.
7-4D-2: CONDITIONS OF CONNECTION OR EXTENSION:
   A.   Sewer Permits Required: No property outside the Village limits shall be
permitted to connect to and be serviced by the Hinsdale sanitary sewer system
without first obtaining a permit therefor and after paying the required fee.
   B.   Approval by the Board of Trustees: No permit shall be issued for such
connection of any property outside the Village and serviced by the Village
sanitary sewer system until application therefor is first approved by the
Village President and Board of Trustees.
   C.   Permit Fees: No permit shall be issued for such connection of any
outside property to a Village sewer until an inspection fee of ten dollars
($10.00) shall have been paid to the Village Treasurer. Permit requirements
shall not apply to outside property already connected to the sewer system of
the Village.
7-4D-3: VILLAGE WATER SERVICES REQUIRED:
No property located outside the corporate limits of the Village shall be
permitted to connect to any Village sewer until and after the premises to be
served by said sewer is already served by a connection to the Village water
supply system. No applications for an outside sewer connection or petition for
a sewer main extension shall be considered by the Village President and Board
of Trustees unless accompanied by suitable evidence that the property will be
served by Village water prior to connection with the sewer system. Any water
mains or services installed to serve property outside the Village corporate
limits shall comply with the provisions relating to water in this Code. 1
 
Notes
1 1. See Chapter 4E of this Title.
   
7-4D-4: OUTSIDE SEWERS PROPERTY OF VILLAGE:
Any sewer main extension approved and installed in compliance herewith to serve
property outside the Village limits shall become the property of the Village
immediately upon installation and connection to the Village sewer and all
easements covering said main shall be assigned to the Village.
7-4D-5: MAINTENANCE OF OUTSIDE SEWERS:
The ordinary maintenance of any outside sewer installed under the provisions
herein shall be assumed by the village in the same general manner as
maintenance of sewers inside the village. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4D-6: LATERAL CONNECTIONS:
Sewer lateral connections from the main sewer to the wall of the building
served shall comply in all respects to the requirements of the village plumbing
code 1  and shall be installed by a licensed plumber. Village plumbing code
requirements or fees for plumbing work inside a building shall not apply to
property outside the village limits. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 9, chapter 5 of this code.
   
7-4D-7: REQUIREMENTS FOR OUTSIDE MAIN EXTENSION:
No extension for the sewer mains by the village to serve property outside the
village limits shall be installed until there is first submitted to the
village, detailed plans and profiles of the proposed work. A surety bond in an
amount equal to the full cost of the extension as estimated by the village, in
favor of the village, guaranteeing that the work shall be performed in
accordance with the plans and specifications shall be furnished before said
work is started. Plans, profiles and specifications shall require the written
approval of the village manager before any such extension to the village sewer
system is installed. If, in the opinion of the village manager, a field
inspector appointed by the village is required to supervise the installation of
any such sewer extension, a cash deposit shall be made prior to starting the
work in an amount specified by the village manager to pay the wages of such
inspector during the period of such installation. Any portion of said deposit
in excess of the sum used to pay the wages of said inspector shall be refunded
to the depositor. The village may require that plans and specifications be
prepared by and construction supervised by a licensed engineer. (Ord., 8-2-
1966)
7-4D-8: STORM WATER PROHIBITED:
The connection of roof downspouts, surface catch basins or other methods of
introducing surface or storm water into any such outside sanitary sewer main is
hereby prohibited. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
ARTICLE E. WATER; GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
7-4E-1: Supervision
7-4E-2: Permit Required
7-4E-3: Use Of Fire Hydrants
7-4E-4: Injury To Water Utility
7-4E-5: Excavation Near Water Mains
7-4E-6: Lawn Sprinkling Restrictions; Penalties
7-4E-7: Fluoride
7-4E-8: WaterSense Products
7-4E-1: SUPERVISION:
The system of water mains and pipes, softening plant, pumping station, grounds,
buildings and appurtenances thereto shall be under the administrative control
of the director of public services subject to the recommendations to the
director of public services by the utilities commission as approved by the
village president and board of trustees and to the direction and authority of
the village president and board of trustees. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4E-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall in any way use or take water for private use from the village
water system or from any pipes or systems connected therewith whether located
inside or outside the village limits, unless such consumer has first applied to
the village for service and has received a permit from the director of public
services.
Before any excavation or other construction work is started for the purpose of
supplying water to any premises, application shall be made and a permit issued
by the director of public services, allowing the installation of the water
service. Said permit shall only be issued by the director after the payment of
all fees required for water services. (Ord., 2-4-1975)
7-4E-3: USE OF FIRE HYDRANTS:
No person, except a regularly authorized agent of the village shall cause water
to flow from any public or private fire hydrant, except that a person other
than such an agent of the village may operate and use water from a fire hydrant
only after a written permit has been issued by the director of public services
permitting such use and only after suitable arrangements, approved by the
director, for payment for such water used have been made. (Ord., 8-1-1972)
7-4E-4: INJURY TO WATER UTILITY:
No person, other than a regularly authorized agent of the village in line of
duty shall interfere in any manner with any public or private fire hydrant,
water main, main line valve or box or commit any act tending to obstruct the
use thereof without first obtaining a permit from the director of public
services. No person shall wilfully or carelessly break, injure, mar, deface,
interfere with or disturb the walls, fixtures, buildings, machinery, apparatus,
fencing, reservoirs, storage tanks or any of the appurtenances of the water
system. (Ord., 8-1-1972)
7-4E-5: EXCAVATION NEAR WATER MAINS:
Any person making an excavation in the vicinity of existing mains shall be
fully responsible for any damage or leakage to or from said water mains and
shall repair immediately such damage or leakage to the satisfaction of the
director of public services and upon failure to do so shall be subject to the
penalties provided herein. (Ord., 8-1-1972)
7-4E-6: LAWN SPRINKLING RESTRICTIONS; PENALTIES:
   A.   General Lawn Sprinkling Restriction: Except as provided in subsections
B and C of this section, lawn sprinkling shall be permitted from May 15 through
September 15 only between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and ten o'clock
(10:00) A.M. and the hours of six o'clock (6:00) P.M. and ten o'clock (10:00)
P.M. and only on the following days:
      1.   Even numbered street addresses: Even numbered calendar days.
      2.   Odd numbered street addresses: Odd numbered calendar days.
      3.   No sprinkling shall be permitted on May 31, July 31, and August 31.
   B.   New Grass Seed Or Sod: Notwithstanding the restrictions stated in
subsection A of this section, the village manager, on the written request of a
property owner or her or his agent, may issue a temporary permit allowing
sprinkling of a lawn with new grass seed or sod. The temporary permit shall be
issued only on a finding by the village manager that sprinkling is necessary to
protect the new seed or sod from damage due to inadequate water. A temporary
permit may be issued for a time period not exceeding thirty (30) days. The
temporary permit must be prominently displayed on the affected property in a
location visible from an adjacent street. The village manager may impose
conditions and limitations on a temporary permit as the village manager deems
necessary or appropriate. No fee shall be charged for a temporary permit.
   C.   Additional Sprinkling And Water Use Restrictions: In addition to the
restrictions stated in subsection A of this section, the village manager may
impose any one or more of the following additional restrictions on sprinkling
if the village manager determines that such restrictions are necessary or
appropriate to protect the village's water supply system:
      1.   A further reduction of allowable lawn sprinkling hours; or
      2.   Limitations on the watering of shrubs, trees, ornamental plants,
gardens, or other vegetation; or
      3.   A complete ban on all outside water usage, including, without
limitation, lawn sprinkling and car washing except by commercial car washing
businesses.
   D.   Violations; Penalties: It shall be unlawful to violate any restriction
imposed by, or pursuant to, this section. Each day on which a violation occurs
shall be deemed a separate violation of this section. Each violation shall be
punishable by a fine up to two hundred dollars ($200.00), according to the
following schedule:
      1.   First violation in any calendar year: Warning citation, no fine.
      2.   Second and subsequent violations in any calendar year:
 
Description Of Violation       Pay In 10 Days Pay In 20 Days Pay After 20 Days
First violation in 30 day      $ 25.00        $ 35.00        $ 50.00
period
Second violation in 30 day     50.00          70.00          100.00
period
Third and additional violation 100.00         140.00         200.00
(s) in 30 day period
 
The time periods set forth in this table run beginning on the day after the
date of issuance of the citation. If payment is not made within thirty (30)
days after the date of issuance of the citation, then a court appearance shall
be required. (Ord. O2005-53, 11-15-2005)
7-4E-7: FLUORIDE:
   A.   Findings: Based upon studies of the special committee of the village
board appointed to study water, fluoride and based on public hearings, the
village president and board of trustees hereby find that it is in the interests
of public health that steps for the introduction of fluoride in a concentration
adequate for safety be taken.
   B.   Fluoride To Be Added: Fluoride shall be added to the village water
supply in quantities sufficient to maintain in the entire village an optimum
fluoride level of one (1.0) part per million parts of water. Said fluoride
shall be added in accordance with regulations prescribed by the Illinois
department of health and the department of public services of the village.
   C.   Effective Date: This section shall be in full force and effect upon its
passage and approval September 7, 1965, as provided by law. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4E-8: WATERSENSE PRODUCTS:
All new plumbing fixtures and irrigation controllers installed on properties
connected to the municipal water supply system shall bear the WaterSense label
(as designated by the United States environmental protection agency WaterSense
program), when such labeled fixtures are available. (Ord. O2016-20, 5-3-2016)
ARTICLE F. WATER METERS
SECTION:
7-4F-1: Metering Of Water; Fees
7-4F-2: Taps; Fees
7-4F-3: Meters Property Of Village
7-4F-4: Meter Testing; Repair And Replacement; Stopped Meter Surcharge; Leakage
And Waste
7-4F-5: Metering During Construction; Fees
7-4F-6: Lien; Notice Of Delinquency
7-4F-7: Foreclosure Of Lien
7-4F-8: Shutting Off Water For Nonpayment (Rep. by Ord., 5-19-1992)
7-4F-9: Unauthorized Turning On Of Water
7-4F-1: METERING OF WATER; FEES:
All water supplied by the village shall be measured by water meters or other
meter reading equipment approved by the director of public services. No water
meter or other meter reading equipment shall be approved and installed until
the fee therefor has been paid to the village as provided in section
9-1-4 of this code. When an old meter or other meter reading equipment becomes
worn beyond repair and is no longer serviceable or is no longer sufficient for
efficient meter reading purposes, it shall be replaced by the village at no
expense to the customer. When a customer wishes to replace a serviceable meter
with one of a different size, that customer shall pay to the village, before
said new meter is installed, the difference between the salvaged value of the
meter to be replaced, as determined by the director of public services, and the
costs of a new meter. (Ord. O99-35, 8-17-1999)
7-4F-2: TAPS; FEES 1 :
All taps to water mains shall be made by the village, and the village shall
furnish corporation cocks, wye fittings, curb stops, and curb stop (buffalo)
boxes as required. No taps shall be made until the fee therefor has been paid
to the village as provided in section
9-1-4 of this code. (Ord., 7-19-1988)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 7-4G-1 of this chapter.
7-4F-3: METERS PROPERTY OF VILLAGE:
All water meters or other meter reading equipment heretofore installed or that
may hereafter be installed are hereby declared to be the exclusive property of
the village regardless of the fact that a service charge to cover the cost
thereof may have been or will be collected from the customer. (Ord. O99-35, 8-
17-1999)
7-4F-4: METER TESTING; REPAIR AND REPLACEMENT; STOPPED METER SURCHARGE; LEAKAGE
AND WASTE:
   A.   The director of public services shall from time to time cause to be
inspected and tested water meters or other meter reading equipment. Between
routine inspections and testing, the director shall cause to be inspected and
tested water meters or other meter reading equipment appearing to be out of
order or appearing to have faulty registration. Any meter or other meter
reading equipment found to be working improperly shall be repaired or replaced
at village expense; provided, however, that if such meter or other meter
reading equipment appears to have been damaged by the negligence of the
customer, then the village shall charge to the customer the cost of repair or
replacement.
   B.   The owner or person in possession, charge or control of any building,
structure or premises in which any village water meter or other meter reading
equipment is installed or located shall at all times permit the director of
public services or any duly authorized officer or employee of the village water
department free entry to such building, structure or premises for the purposes
of examining, reading, testing, repairing or replacing such meter or other
meter reading equipment.
   C.   If at any time a meter or other meter reading equipment fails to
accurately register the quantity of water passing through the meter for two (2)
or less billing periods, the water billing quantity shall be estimated based on
the customer's prior usage.
   D.   If it is determined that a meter or other meter reading equipment has
failed to accurately register the quantity of water for three (3) or more
billing periods, the customer's account shall be subject to a stopped meter
surcharge in order to partially recover revenue lost through under billing. The
stopped meter surcharge shall be calculated at thirty percent (30%) of the
current water charge and shall remain in effect for the same number of billing
periods that a meter did not function, not to exceed one year. The stopped
meter surcharge shall be in addition to all other applicable water and sewer
charges.
   E.   The customer shall be responsible for maintaining all pipes and
fixtures on the owned premises and no credit shall be given on excess meter
charges caused by leakage and waste on the customer's premises, whether known
or not. (Ord. O2011-45, 10-24-2011)
7-4F-5: METERING DURING CONSTRUCTION; FEES:
No building permit shall be issued until the water service fee therefor has
been paid to the village as provided in section
9-1-4 of this code, covering use of unmetered water during construction. The
director of public services, in his or her sole discretion, may require
installation of a temporary outside meter to measure water used during
construction if he or she determines that such water use may be greater than
that typically used during construction operations in the village. The
installation of such temporary outside meter shall not relieve the building
permit applicant of the duty to pay the water service fee. Water measured by
any such temporary outside meter shall be paid for at the village's regular
metered water rates. (Ord., 7-19-1988)
7-4F-6: LIEN; NOTICE OF DELINQUENCY 1 :
Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid thirty (30) days after it has
been rendered, the village attorney shall file with the county recorder of
deeds of DuPage County, if the property is situated in DuPage County or with
the county recorder of deeds of Cook County if the property is situated in Cook
County, a statement of lien claim.
This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the
amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this
amount as well as for all charges for water subsequent to the period covered by
the bill.
If the consumer of water whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises,
the village attorney, if he has notice of this, shall mail or have mailed a
notice to the owner of the premises, if his address be known to the attorney,
whenever such bill remains unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days after it has
been rendered.
The failure of the village attorney to record such lien claim or to mail such
notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the
right to foreclose the lien for unpaid water bills as mentioned in the
following section. (Ord., 8-26-1966)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 7-4B-4 of this chapter.
7-4F-7: FORECLOSURE OF LIEN:
Property subject to a lien for unpaid water charges shall be sold for
nonpayment of same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay the
charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory
liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in the name of the village.
The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such
proceedings in the name of the village in any court having jurisdiction over
such matters, against any property for which the bill for water has remained
unpaid thirty (30) days after it has been rendered. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
7-4F-8: SHUTTING OFF WATER FOR NONPAYMENT:
(Rep. by Ord., 5-19-1992)
7-4F-9: UNAUTHORIZED TURNING ON OF WATER:
No plumber or other person shall turn on the supply of water to any building or
premises prior to the installation of a meter on all service lines installed,
or shall allow the same to be done without a permit from the director of public
services; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to
prevent plumbers from turning on water to test the piping and fixtures and for
providing water for construction purposes, in which case the plumber shall turn
off the water as soon as these needs are met. (Ord., 8-2-1966)
