CHAPTER 6
NEWSRACKS
SECTION:
7-6-1: Definition
7-6-2: Certificate Of Compliance Required
7-6-3: Application For Certificate
7-6-4: Certificate Of Compliance Fee
7-6-5: Newsrack Inspection And Maintenance Fee
7-6-6: Issuance Or Denial Of Certificate
7-6-7: Multiple Newsrack Areas
7-6-8: Regulations Applicable To All Newsracks
7-6-9: Nonconforming Newsracks
7-6-10: Nuisance Declared
7-6-11: Notice; Removal For Noncompliance
7-6-12: Abandoned Newsracks
7-6-13: Penalty
7-6-1: DEFINITION:
The term "newsrack" shall mean, for the purposes of this chapter, any self-
service or coin operated box, container, storage unit, or other dispenser
designed, intended, used, placed, installed, or maintained for the display and
sale or distribution of newspapers, periodicals, or other publications. (Ord.
O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-2: CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
No person shall place, affix, erect, or construct, install, or maintain a
newsrack on any public street, highway, sidewalk, parkway, alley, or other
public right of way without first obtaining a certificate of compliance
therefor in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-
16-2002)
7-6-3: APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE:
An application for a certificate of compliance shall be filed with the village
clerk and reviewed by the village engineer on a form provided by the village
therefor, and every application shall include the following information and
materials:
   A.   The name, address, and telephone number of the applicant, who shall be
the owner of, or principal in charge of, the newsrack(s); and
   B.   The name, address, and telephone number of a responsible person whom
the village may notify or contact at any time concerning the newsrack(s); and
   C.   The number of newsracks and the proposed location of each newsrack,
shown on a drawing provided by the village as part of the application form; and
   D.   The type or brand of the newsrack(s), including an illustration and
description of the newsrack and mount; and
   E.   A description of the newsrack(s), including height, width, and depth
dimensions, color, lettering, decorative elements, operational features,
capacity, name and cost of the publication to be dispensed, and other features;
and
   F.   A check in the amount of twenty five dollars ($25.00), pursuant to
section
7-6-4 of this chapter; and
   G.   A check in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) for each proposed
newsrack, pursuant to section
7-6-5 of this chapter; and
   H.   All other information reasonably required by the village engineer to
ascertain compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-
2002)
7-6-4: CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE FEE:
Every application shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) as payment of the costs of review, inspection, and
administration of the application. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-5: NEWSRACK INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE FEE:
Every application shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount of ten dollars
($10.00) per newsrack as payment of the costs of review, inspection, and
administration of the newsracks. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-6: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF CERTIFICATE:
   A.   The village engineer shall issue, within five (5) business days after a
properly completed application therefor, a certificate of compliance for each
newsrack that complies with all of the regulations provided in sections
7-6-7 and
7-6-8 of this chapter; provided, however, that no certificate shall be issued
until after payment of the required fees therefor.
   B.   The village engineer shall, within ten (10) business days, deny a
certificate of compliance for any newsrack that does not comply with any one or
more of said regulations. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-7: MULTIPLE NEWSRACK AREAS:
   A.   The village may designate, from time to time, a certain area within the
village as a multiple newsrack area. The following area is hereby designated as
a multiple newsrack area:
      1.   That portion of the downtown area of the village bounded by Maple
Street on the north, Garfield Avenue on the east, First Street on the south,
and Washington Street on the west is a multiple newsrack area.
   B.   The following additional areas may be designated by motion adopted by
the board of trustees:
      1.   That portion of the village bounded by Railroad Avenue on the north,
Stough Street on the east, Hinsdale Avenue on the south, and Illinois Route 83
on the west is a multiple newsrack area; and
      2.   That portion of the village bounded by Hillgrove Avenue on the
north, County Line Road extended on the east, Chicago Avenue on the south, and
Oak Street on the west is a multiple newsrack area.
   C.   No person shall place or maintain any newsrack within a multiple
newsrack area except multiple newsracks placed and maintained by the village.
Such multiple newsracks shall be maintained for publications on request. Such
multiple newsracks shall be subject to the following standards:
      1.   The number of multiple newsracks in the multiple newsrack area shall
be established by the village engineer, shall be sufficient in number to
accommodate all publications located in single newsracks as of July 1, 2002,
and shall be reasonably sufficient to accommodate general demand.
      2.   A publication shall be assigned a compartment upon application
therefor by the publisher.
      3.   All publications with at least five (5) different daily editions
each week shall be assigned a compartment in each multiple newsrack. If the
number of additional publications seeking placement exceeds available
compartments, then a random selection process shall be used to determine which
publications shall be eligible for compartments.
      4.   Compartments shall be assigned randomly. For publications
distributed on a paid basis, the assignments shall begin with the first
available top left compartment, proceeding downward and left to right. For
publications not distributed on a paid basis, the assignments shall begin with
the top right compartment, proceeding downward and right to left.
      5.   Any compartment that remains empty for thirty (30) days or longer
shall be deemed vacant and may be assigned to another publication pursuant to
this chapter. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-8: REGULATIONS APPLICABLE TO ALL NEWSRACKS:
   A.   Placement In Relation To Curb: No newsrack shall be placed closer than
twenty four inches (24") to the edge of any curb. No newsrack shall be placed
further than thirty six inches (36") from the edge of any curb; provided,
however, that the village engineer may authorize and direct that a newsrack be
placed near the wall of a building if the village engineer determines that
public safety considerations preclude placement of the newsrack near the curb
at or near the location requested in the application. All newsracks placed near
the curb shall be placed parallel to, and facing away from, the curb. All
newsracks placed near the wall of a building shall be placed not further than
six inches (6") from such wall.
   B.   Placement In Relation To Crosswalk: No newsrack shall be located within
five feet (5') of any crosswalk or within ten feet (10') of any intersection
where no crosswalk is marked.
   C.   Placement In Relation To Emergency Facilities: No newsrack shall be
located within ten feet (10') of any fire hydrant, fire call box, police call
box, or any other emergency facility.
   D.   Placement In Relation To Commuter Facilities: No newsrack shall be
located within five feet (5') of any bus bench, plaza bench, doorway to any
commuter passenger station or any sign or other marking designating a bus stop.
   E.   Placement In Relation To Landscaped Areas: No newsrack shall be placed
within two feet (2') of any area improved with lawn, hedges, flowers, trees, or
other landscaping elements.
   F.   Placement In Relation To Doorways: No newsrack shall be placed within
five feet (5') of any doorway.
   G.   Placement In Relation To Windows: No newsrack shall be placed within
three feet (3') of, or in any manner impeding the reasonable view or use for
display purposes of, any window.
   H.   Placement In Relation To Other Newsracks With Same Publication: No
newsrack shall be placed within one hundred fifty feet (150') of any other
newsrack containing the same newspaper or news periodical.
   I.   Placement In Relation To Other Newsrack Generally: No newsrack shall be
placed facing another newsrack.
   J.   Placement In Relation To Poles, Parking Meters, Streetlights, Traffic
Control Devices: No newsrack shall be placed within two feet (2') of any
utility pole, parking meter, streetlight, or traffic control sign or device.
   K.   Minimum Width Of Useable Passageway: No newsrack shall be placed in any
location that reduces the width of a pedestrian passageway to less than five
feet (5').
   L.   Maintenance: All newsracks shall be maintained in a clean, freshly
painted, smoothly operating, and orderly condition at all times. All newsracks
shall be kept free at all times of debris, litter, graffiti, bumper stickers,
and other markings. Dirty newsracks shall be promptly cleaned. Broken, dented,
or poorly operating newsracks shall be promptly repaired or replaced.
   M.   Dimensions: No newsrack shall exceed the following dimensions:
      1.   Height: Thirty six inches (36") above the sidewalk or other surface
on which it is placed, plus not more than thirteen inches (13") for a coin
slot.
      2.   Width: Twenty inches (20").
      3.   Depth: Twenty inches (20").
   N.   Card Holders: No newsrack shall include a card holder except only for
the name of the publication to be dispensed from such newsrack and
announcements directly related to the content of such publication.
   O.   Advertisements Prohibited: Except as provided in subsection N of this
section, no newsrack shall include or display any advertisement of any goods,
product, or service.
   P.   Private Newsracks Prohibited In Multiple Newsrack Area: No person shall
place or maintain any newsrack in the multiple newsrack area placed and
maintained by the village. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-9: NONCONFORMING NEWSRACKS:
Within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this chapter, any newsrack
that does not comply with any regulation of this chapter shall be brought
immediately into compliance, and thereafter all newsracks shall at all times be
maintained in compliance, with all of the regulations of this chapter or shall
be removed. Any newsrack not so brought into, or maintained in, compliance or
removed shall be removed by the village engineer, subject to the provisions of
section
7-6-11 of this chapter. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-10: NUISANCE DECLARED:
Any newsrack that is placed, affixed, erected, constructed, installed, or
maintained on any public street, highway, sidewalk, parkway, alley, or other
public right of way in violation of any provision of this chapter is hereby
declared a public nuisance and may be removed at any time by the village
engineer, subject to the provisions of section
7-6-11 of this chapter. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-11: NOTICE; REMOVAL FOR NONCOMPLIANCE:
If any newsrack is installed, used, or maintained in violation of the
provisions of this chapter, then the village engineer shall give seven (7)
days' written notice of violation and an opportunity to cure such violation(s)
to the person identified pursuant to subsection 7-6-3B of this chapter. If any
violation remains after the seven (7) day period has expired, then the newsrack
may be removed immediately by the village. If the owner of, or person
responsible for, the newsrack is unknown, or if the placement of the newsrack
creates a danger to the public, then the village may summarily remove it and
store it in any convenient place as provided herein. The village then shall
take reasonable steps to notify the owner of the newsrack. Upon failure of any
owner to claim, within sixty (60) days, a newsrack that has been removed and
stored by the village, and to pay within said sixty (60) days the village's
expenses for such removal and storage, such newsrack shall be deemed to be
unclaimed property in possession of the village and may be disposed of pursuant
to state law and village ordinances governing the disposition of unclaimed
property. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-12: ABANDONED NEWSRACKS:
Any newsrack that, at any time, does not contain a current edition of the
publication specified therefor for seventy two (72) consecutive hours or
longer, or that is empty at any time for seven (7) consecutive days or longer,
shall be deemed abandoned, regardless of any intent or purpose of the owner or
operator thereof to use or not to abandon such newsrack. Every abandoned
newsrack may be removed immediately by the village engineer. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-
16-2002)
7-6-13: PENALTY:
Any person who violates this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for
each offense. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be
considered a separate offense. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
CHAPTER 7
COMMERCIAL FILMING, PHOTOGRAPHY AND TAPING ACTIVITIES
SECTION:
7-7-1: Permit Required
7-7-2: General And Automobile Liability Insurance Required
7-7-3: Hold Harmless And Indemnification Agreement
7-7-4: Fees And Remuneration For Use Of Public Property/Personnel/Equipment
7-7-5: Notification; Pre-Production Meeting
7-7-6: Village Recognition
7-7-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   Application: The Village Manager may authorize the use of any street,
right-of-way, or public building, equipment or personnel for commercial uses in
the filming, photography or taping of movies, television programs, commercials,
or training films and related activities. In conjunction with these uses, the
Village Manager requires that any or all of the conditions and/or remunerations
as specified on the application be met as a prerequisite to that use. The
application must be filed with the Village Manager, and is subject to the
following time lines:
      1.   For small productions (combination of vehicles and crew totaling ten
(10) or less):
Initial application: Filed not less than fifteen (15) business days prior to
filming, photography or taping.
Decision on initial application by Village: Not less than ten (10) business
days prior to filming, photography or taping.
Final application completed with resident notifications: Not less than five (5)
business days prior to filming, photography or taping.
      2.   For large productions (combination of vehicles and crew totaling
eleven (11) or more):
Initial application: Filed not less than thirty (30) business days prior to
filming, photography or taping.
Decision on initial application by Village: Not less than twenty (20) business
days prior to filming, photography or taping.
Final application completed with resident notifications: Not less than ten (10)
business days prior to filming, photography or taping.
The applicant shall agree, as part of the application, that the Village shall
have full control over the use of public streets and buildings of the Village
while being used, as well as control over the hours of production and the
general location of the production. The Village reserves the full and absolute
right to prohibit all filming, photography or taping, to impose such conditions
on filming, photography or taping as are necessary to ensure that such filming,
photography or taping is not unduly disruptive or otherwise detrimental to the
public health, safety and welfare, or to order cessation of filming,
photography or taping if determined to be unduly disruptive or otherwise
detrimental to the public health, safety, and welfare.
The applicant shall agree to allow the respective Village departments (i.e.,
Police, Fire, Building) to inspect all structures and/or devices and equipment
to be used in connection with the filming, photography and taping if required
by the Village Manager.
   B.   Investigation: The Village Manager shall refer the application to the
Police Department and to the Fire and Building Departments, as deemed
necessary, for investigation. The Village Manager may, in his or her sole
discretion, refer the application to the Village Board of Trustees for review
and input, including recommendations on any conditions necessary to ensure the
filming, photography or taping is not unduly disruptive or otherwise
detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare.
   C.   Time Limits On Activity: Filming, photography and taping activities,
including set up and clean up, shall generally be allowed between the hours of
eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M., Monday - Saturday. No
filming, photography, or taping activities shall be allowed on Sundays or the
following federal holidays: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor
Day, Thanksgiving, and Christmas. A request to film, photograph or tape outside
of these hours requires the written approval of the Village Manager. In
addition, the Village Manager may restrict or limit the time for filming,
photographing or taping activities during rush-hour traffic or during periods
when schools or churches are in session within the affected area, or whenever,
in his or her judgment, circumstances warrant such limitation. The Village
Manager and a representative of the applicant shall agree to a time daily past
which no filming, photography or taping shall occur. The applicant shall be
fined at a rate established by the Village Manager for any filming, photography
or taping that occurs past the agreed upon time. Only one filming, photography
or taping production shall be authorized in the Village on any given day. The
Village restricts the commercial filming of the exterior or interior of any
single private residence to no more than three (3) consecutive days and no more
than ten (10) days per calendar year. This limit may be waived only with the
express written permission of the Village Manager based on unique
circumstances. The Village also restricts the filming by any single production
company to no more than three (3) consecutive days and no more than ten (10)
days per calendar year. This limit may be waived only with the express written
permission of the Village Manager based on unique circumstances.
   D.   Report Of Vehicles And Equipment: The applicant shall provide a report
listing the number of vehicles and types of equipment to be used during the
filming, photography or taping, including the proposed hours of use and the
proposed parking locations. All such parking locations shall be reviewed and
approved by the Village Manager prior to their use. Every applicant shall pay
the full daily rate for every metered or permit parking space occupied by any
vehicles and equipment. Equipment nonessential to actual filming should be kept
at a project base camp which will be determined in conjunction with the Village
Manager's Office.
   E.   Village Control Over Public Streets, Buildings And Filming Activities:
The Village shall have full and complete control over the use of public streets
and buildings of the Village while being used for filming, photographing or
taping activities, as well as control over the hours of production and the
general location of the production. The Village reserves the full and absolute
right to prohibit all filming, photography or taping or to order cessation of
filming, photography or taping if determined to be detrimental to the public
health, safety and welfare, and the applicant shall acknowledge its
understanding and agreement of these Municipal powers as part of the
application.
   F.   Termination Of Permit: Any permit issued herein may be terminated by
the Village Manager in the event of a violation of any of the conditions and
requirements established by the Village Manager pursuant to this chapter, or of
any traffic law or other Village regulation, or of a deviation in the
production schedule, number of vehicles, equipment location or any other
information furnished by the applicant with respect to the permit application.
   G.   Village Manager Designee: Any or all of the duties and functions of the
Village Manager under this chapter may be performed by his or her designee.
(Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-2015; amd. Ord. O2019-35, 10-15-2019)
7-7-2: GENERAL AND AUTOMOBILE LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED:
The applicant shall furnish the Village Manager with a certificate of liability
insurance naming the Village, its Corporate Authorities, officers, officials,
boards, commissions, employees, attorneys, agents and representatives as
additional insureds with respect to any and all claims which arise out of, or
are in any way related to, the operations of the applicant within the Village
in connection with the particular commercial filming, photography or taping
activity for which a permit is sought, in the general liability amount of one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death to any person or for
damage to any property from any occurrence arising out of or in any way related
to the applicant within the Village, and automobile liability, if applicable,
in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00), including bodily injury
and property damage. The applicant shall also submit to the Village Manager
proof of the appropriate workers' compensation and employer's liability
insurance in force with respect to employees of the applicant. (Ord. O2015-53,
12-8-2015)
7-7-3: HOLD HARMLESS AND INDEMNIFICATION AGREEMENT:
In addition to the insurance requirement, the applicant shall enter into a hold
harmless and indemnification agreement, on a form as provided by the Village
Manager, to hold the Village and its Corporate Authorities, officers,
officials, boards, commissions, employees, attorneys, agents and
representatives harmless, and to defend and indemnify the Village with respect
to any loss, judgment, damages, costs and expenses, settlement and compromises,
claims and causes of action of every kind or nature, arising out of or in any
way related to the operations of the applicant within the Village in connection
with the commercial filming, photography or taping activities within the
Village for which a permit is issued. (Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-2015)
7-7-4: FEES AND REMUNERATION FOR USE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY/PERSONNEL/EQUIPMENT:
The applicant shall pay the following permit fees and costs for use of public
buildings and areas, and Village personnel, vehicles and equipment. The fee for
processing the permit provided in this section shall be five hundred dollars
($500.00) for small productions (combination of vehicles and crew totaling ten
(10) or less) and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for large productions
(combination of vehicles and crew totaling eleven (11) or more) and shall be
nonrefundable. This fee is intended to cover the cost of Village personnel
reviewing and processing the application.
Next, the following fees shall be a one-time, nonrefundable charge based on the
type of production and the length of production. All fees will be paid upfront
before the production commences:
 
Still photography shoots                      $ 200.00
Filming productions lasting 5 days or fewer   500.00
Filming productions lasting more than 5 days  1,000.00
and up to 10 days
Filming productions lasting more than 10 days An additional $75.00 per day fee
 
If special parking restrictions are necessary to accommodate the production, an
additional fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) will be charged to all
permit holders.
In addition, the cost of use of police, public safety, public works or other
Village personnel assigned to the permit activity (whether requested by the
applicant or not) shall be one and a half times the employee's hourly rate of
pay. Examples of employee staff time include traffic control and enforcement.
The Village reserves the right to determine when use of Village personnel is
required and warranted. To the extent that the Village will be required to
utilize Village vehicles and equipment, the Village will require reimbursement
for the hourly rate associated with each vehicle or piece of equipment.
Next, the rate for use of public property shall be determined by the Village
Manager according to the extent of such use as follows: for total or disruptive
use of a public building during regular operating hours, eight hundred twenty
five dollars ($825.00) per day plus seventy dollars ($70.00) per hour for each
hour or part thereof beyond regular operating hours; for partial, non-
disruptive use of such public building, five hundred ten dollars ($510.00) per
day plus thirty five dollars ($35.00) per hour for each hour or part thereof
beyond regular operating hours; for total closure of a public street, park area
or right-of-way, eighty dollars ($80.00) per hour; for partial closure or
obstruction of such public street, park area or right-of-way, forty dollars
($40.00) per hour. Applicant will be responsible for obtaining permission from
BNSF if filming, photography or taping on rail tracks is requested and for
providing any required flagmen and/or road signage. The Village Manager may
waive part or all the fees for a nonprofit organization at his or her
discretion. (Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-2015; amd. Ord. O2019-35, 10-15-2019)
7-7-5: NOTIFICATION; PRE-PRODUCTION MEETING:
The applicant shall be required to contact any or all property owner(s) and
residents in the affected neighborhood as defined by boundaries set by the
Village Manager. The applicant shall write a short description of the proposed
project along with the filming, photography or taping schedule to distribute to
the property owners or residents. The applicant shall provide a report
attesting to such distribution and noting any owner's or resident's reaction
along with the addresses and phone numbers of all reacting property owners.
This completed report must be delivered to the Office of the Village Manager
prior to approval for filming, photography or taping. The Village reserves the
right to not allow filming, photography or taping in any location where any of
the property owners in the affected neighborhood file written objections to
such filming, photography or taping. The applicant may also be required to meet
with Village staff at least forty eight (48) hours in advance of the desired
production date at the discretion of Village staff. (Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-2015;
amd. Ord. O2019-35, 10-15-2019)
7-7-6: VILLAGE RECOGNITION:
The Village shall be duly recognized in the publication of any film, tape, book
or periodical, which includes therein public buildings or public areas of the
Village. (Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-2015; amd. Ord. O2019-35, 10-15-2019)
TITLE 8
FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION
CHAPTER 1
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
8-1-1: Department Created
8-1-2: Fire Chief; Office Created
8-1-3: Fire Chief; Compensation
8-1-4: Fire Chief; Powers And Duties
8-1-4-1: Shift Commanders
8-1-5: Appointments, Promotions And Discharges
8-1-5-1: Residency
8-1-6: Powers And Duties Of Firefighters Generally
8-1-7: Directing Department At Fires
8-1-8: Removing Property To Prevent Spread Of Fire
8-1-9: Paid On Call Firefighters
8-1-10: Claiming Property Saved From Fire
8-1-11: Entering Fire Department Premises
8-1-12: Using Fire Apparatus
8-1-13: Driving Over Unprotected Hose
8-1-14: Obstructing Use Of Fire Hydrant
8-1-15: Duties Of Persons To Aid Firefighters
8-1-16: Building Or Fire Hazards; Duty To Remedy
8-1-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created a fire department, an executive department of the
village, which shall be under the jurisdiction of the village manager. The fire
department shall consist of the fire chief and such other officers, in such
numbers, as may be authorized by the village president and board of trustees
from time to time, including captains (who are designated as shift commanders),
lieutenants, firefighter/EMT-Bs, firefighters, and firefighter/paramedics.
(Ord. O2002-31, 5-21-2002; amd. Ord. O2024-09, eff. 5-31-2024)
8-1-2: FIRE CHIEF; OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created the office of fire chief. The fire chief shall be
appointed by the village president and confirmed by the board of trustees upon
the recommendation of the village manager. The fire chief shall serve until
such time as he or she resigns or is removed or discharged from office by the
village manager; provided, however, that the village manager shall provide to
the board of trustees a statement of reasons for removal or discharge, and
provided further that no such removal or discharge shall become effective
unless confirmed by a majority vote of the village president and board of
trustees. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-3: FIRE CHIEF; COMPENSATION:
The fixed salary of the fire chief shall be approved and fixed by the village
president and board of trustees upon the recommendation of the village manager.
(Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-4: FIRE CHIEF; POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Fire Chief shall be in command of the Fire Department and shall be subject
to the supervision of the Village Manager. The Fire Chief shall be responsible
for the daily operation and routine management of the Fire Department. The Fire
Chief shall be responsible for the performance by the Fire Department of all
its functions, and all members of the Fire Department shall serve subject to
the orders of the Fire Chief. The specific powers and duties of the Fire Chief
shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
   A.   Assigning duties to members of the Fire Department;
   B.   Serving as custodian of and maintaining in good condition all property
and equipment belonging to the Fire Department;
   C.   Promulgating departmental rules and regulations in accordance with
standard Village procedures necessary to properly carry out the functions of
the Fire Department; provided, however, that such rules and regulations shall
not take effect unless approved by the Village Manager;
   D.   Keeping or causing to be kept a record of all fires and of any other
emergency assistance rendered by the Fire Department, including the names of
firefighters in attendance;
   E.   Preparing a record of the expenses of the Fire Department;
   F.   Preparing a record of all meetings of the Fire Department;
   G.   Entering the premises on which a fire has occurred, when necessary, to
investigate and determine the cause, origin, and circumstances of such fire;
and
   H.   Appointing Shift Commanders, to the extent allowed by law. (Ord. O2004-
49, 10-5-2004; amd. Ord. O2024-09, eff. 5-31-2024)
8-1-4-1: SHIFT COMMANDERS:
The captains are designated as the shift commander of each shift. (Ord. O2004-
49, 10-5-2004; amd. Ord. O2024-09, eff. 5-31-2024)
8-1-5: APPOINTMENTS, PROMOTIONS AND DISCHARGES:
Appointments to and promotions within the fire department, other than to the
offices of fire chief and, to the extent allowed by law, captain, shall be made
by the board of fire and police commissioners in the manner provided by state
law. No nonprobationary firefighter shall be discharged except after a hearing
on charges before the board of fire and police commissioners as provided by
law. The board of fire and police commissioners may discharge probationary
firefighters at any time without prior notice or hearing pursuant to such rules
and procedures, if any, as may be adopted by said board for such cases. Nothing
in this section shall be construed as affecting the power of the village
president to appoint and the village manager to remove or discharge the fire
chief pursuant to section
8-1-2 of this chapter, or the power of the fire chief to appoint and the
village manager to approve captains, to the extent allowed by law. (Ord. O2004-
49, 10-5-2004; amd. Ord. O2024-09, eff. 5-31-2024)
8-1-5-1: RESIDENCY:
Each full time member of the fire department shall reside within the greater
Chicago metropolitan area, that is, within one of the following counties: Cook,
DuPage, Kane, Lake, McHenry, or Will. Any failure to comply with this residency
requirement shall be deemed cause for discharge from the service of the
village, and any full time member who shall fail to comply may be discharged in
the manner provided by law. A full time member shall have one year after
completion of her or his probationary period within which to comply with this
residency requirement. (Ord. O2004-30, 6-1-2004)
8-1-6: POWERS AND DUTIES OF FIREFIGHTERS GENERALLY:
It shall be the duty of all firefighters to prevent and extinguish accidental
or destructive fires; to mitigate the results of, and to render aid in the case
of, accident or disaster and to perform such other duties in the preservation
of life and property as may be assigned.
All firefighters shall have the responsibilities, authority, and liability
prescribed by state statute, this code, and other village ordinances for
firefighters. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as creating any duty
to any specific member of the public. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-7: DIRECTING DEPARTMENT AT FIRES:
The fire chief or, in the absence of the fire chief, the firefighter of the
highest rank in attendance shall take command at a fire and shall direct the
efforts of the fire department to extinguish the fire. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-8: REMOVING PROPERTY TO PREVENT SPREAD OF FIRE:
The fire chief, or in the absence of the fire chief, the firefighter in command
at a fire may cause property to be removed and buildings to be torn down or
destroyed when necessary to prevent the spread of fire to other property.
(Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-9: PAID ON CALL FIREFIGHTERS:
The fire chief with the advice and consent of the village manager may appoint
paid on call firefighters up to such number as the board of trustees shall from
time to time deem necessary. Paid on call firefighters shall be members of the
fire department when on duty. The fire chief with the advice and consent of the
village manager may revoke appointments at any time. Paid on call firefighters
shall be compensated for their services at such rate as the village president
and board of trustees shall approve and fix. The village may provide insurance
to paid on call firefighters, to cover in line of duty accidents only, upon the
recommendation of the village manager with the approval of the village
president and board of trustees. (Ord., 12-16-1991; amd. Ord., 11-1-1994)
8-1-10: CLAIMING PROPERTY SAVED FROM FIRE:
Only persons making satisfactory proof of ownership to the fire chief or, in
the absence of the fire chief, the firefighter in command shall be entitled to
claim any property saved by the fire department from a fire. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-11: ENTERING FIRE DEPARTMENT PREMISES:
Only persons having business pertaining to the fire department or with
authorization from personnel of the fire department shall enter fire department
premises or any place where the equipment and apparatus of the fire department
is stored. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-12: USING FIRE APPARATUS:
Only persons with authorization from the fire chief or, in the absence of the
fire chief, the firefighter in command shall remove any fire engine, hose, or
other apparatus from its place of deposit and use such for any private purpose.
(Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-13: DRIVING OVER UNPROTECTED HOSE:
Only persons with authorization from the fire chief or, in the absence of the
fire chief, the firefighter in command shall drive any automobile, truck, or
other vehicle over unprotected hose laid down by the fire department on any
street or alley. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-14: OBSTRUCTING USE OF FIRE HYDRANT:
No person shall in any manner obstruct the use of any fire hydrant, or have or
place any material in front of any fire hydrant. Any such material found
obstructing any fire hydrant may be removed by fire department personnel at the
risk and expense of the owner or claimant of such material. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-15: DUTIES OF PERSONS TO AID FIREFIGHTERS:
It shall be the duty of all persons when called upon by a firefighter for
assistance to promptly aid the firefighter in the discharge of his or her
duties. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-16: BUILDING OR FIRE HAZARDS; DUTY TO REMEDY:
No owner, lessee, or other person having lawful possession or control of any
premises, building, or other structure shall permit such premises, building, or
structure to become especially liable to fire, or to become liable to cause
injury or damage by collapse or other cause, or to endanger persons or property
by reason of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair, or any other
cause. No owner, lessee, or other person having lawful possession or control of
any premises, building or other structure shall keep, maintain or allow to be
kept or maintained in or on such premises, building, or other structure
combustible or explosive materials which may endanger the safety of said
premises, building or other structure or any person. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
CHAPTER 2
MUTUAL AID
(Rep. by Ord., 12-16-1991)
CHAPTER 3
FIRE PREVENTION CODE
(Rep. by Ord., 7-19-1988)
CHAPTER 4
FIREWORKS
SECTION:
8-4-1: Fireworks Prohibited
8-4-1: FIREWORKS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at
retail, use or explode any fireworks within the village. For the purpose of
this section, the term "fireworks" shall mean and include any explosive
composition, or any substance or combination of substances, or article prepared
for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect of a temporary
exhibitional nature by explosion, combustion, deflagration or detonation, and
shall include blank cartridges, toy cannons, in which explosives are used, the
type of balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same,
firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, sparklers, bombs or other
fireworks of like construction and any fireworks containing any explosive
compound, or any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance, or
containing combustible substances producing visual effects; provided, however,
that the term "fireworks" shall not include toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns or
other devices in which paper or plastic caps containing twenty five- hundredths
(0.25) grain or less of explosive compound are used; provided, they are so
constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for
the explosion. The sale and use of toy pistol paper or plastic caps which
contain less than twenty-hundredths (0.20) grain of explosive mixture shall be
permitted at all times. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the use and explosion of
fireworks shall be permitted when specifically authorized by the village board
of trustees in connection with a village sponsored holiday event. All permitted
fireworks displays and/or pyrotechnic displays shall comply with the Illinois
fireworks use act, 425 Illinois Compiled Statutes 35/0.01 et seq., as amended,
and the Illinois pyrotechnic distributor and operator licensing act, 225
Illinois Compiled Statutes 227/1 et seq., as amended, and any regulations
promulgated by the office of the state fire marshal pursuant thereto. (Ord.
O2006-40, 6-6-2006)
CHAPTER 5
PUBLIC ASSEMBLY HALLS
SECTION:
8-5-1: Regulations
8-5-2: Inspections
8-5-3: Premises Requirements
8-5-4: Notice
8-5-1: REGULATIONS:
It shall be unlawful to hold, manage or conduct any meeting or entertainment of
any kind in the village, in any premises other than a building constructed in
full compliance with the village ordinances and laws pertaining thereto for
auditorium, theater or lodge room purposes, excepting in compliance with the
provisions of this chapter. (1965 Code, sec. 27-3.01)
8-5-2: INSPECTIONS:
No such gathering or entertainment shall be held or presented in any premises
other than a building as described in the preceding section, unless such
premises have been examined by the building commissioner not more than three
(3) days before the date of such gathering and found to be free from any fire
hazard and found to be suitable for the purpose. No structure enclosed by a
roof shall be used for such purpose unless the same is constructed of
nonflammable materials. Provided that tents or structures covered by canvas or
similar materials may be so used if such canvas or other material has been
properly treated so as to be rendered fire resistive. (1965 Code, sec. 27-3.02)
8-5-3: PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Exits: Adequate unobstructed exits shall be provided in all premises
used for such purposes to permit rapid egress of all persons attending, and
there shall be at least two (2) separate exits located at least thirty feet
(30') from each other. (1965 Code, sec. 27-3.03)
   B.   Seats: Any stand or rows of seats used in such premises shall be so
constructed as to be safe for the use designated, and shall be sufficiently
strong to carry the same weight and stress as is required for the construction
of the auditorium floors of theater buildings, not less than one hundred (100)
pounds per square foot.
It shall be unlawful to admit to any such premises a number of persons to
exceed the number of actual seats maintained for their accommodation. (1965
Code, sec. 27-3.04)
   C.   Doors: All doors or gates or exits from premises used for such purposes
shall open outward and no such exit shall be so constructed or locked that
egress from inside the premises is blocked. (1965 Code, sec. 27-3.05)
8-5-4: NOTICE:
It shall be the duty of any person conducting, calling for or managing any
gathering in any premises other than a theater, lodge room or auditorium
building constructed as provided in section
8-5-1 of this chapter, to notify the village clerk of the date of such intended
use at least ten (10) days before such meeting is to take place; upon such
notice the building commissioner shall inspect the premises to determine
whether or not it complies with the provisions hereof. Any permit issued for
any such gathering shall be subject to the condition that this chapter is fully
complied with, whether or not such condition is embodied in the permit. (1965
Code, sec. 27-3.06)
TITLE 9
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Permits Required
9-1-2: Applications For Permits
9-1-3: Approval Of Plans
9-1-4: Permit Fees
9-1-5: Public Property Damage Escrow And Insurance Requirements
9-1-6: Enforcement Of Provisions
9-1-7: Standards And Conditions Applicable To All Work
9-1-7-1: Standards And Conditions Applicable To Demolitions Of Dwellings
9-1-7-2: Personal Visits To Neighbors By Permit Applicants
9-1-8: Site Supervision; Stop Orders
9-1-8-1: Revocation Of Permits
9-1-9: Certificates Of Use And Occupancy
9-1-10: Compliance With Ordinances Required
9-1-11: Nuisance Declared
9-1-12: Abatement
9-1-13: Penalty
9-1-14: Appeals
9-1-1: PERMITS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to construct, enlarge, alter, or demolish a structure, or
to change the occupancy of a building or structure in a manner requiring
greater strength, exitway, or sanitary provisions, or to change to another use,
or to install or alter any equipment for which provision is made in or the
installation of which is regulated by this code, or to conduct land disturbing
activities, or to conduct paving or surfacing of the ground, or handle,
process, or serve food or drink, without first filing an application with the
building commissioner in writing and obtaining the required permits therefor as
required by this title; except that ordinary repairs, as defined in the
international building code hereinafter adopted by reference, shall be exempt
from this provision.
(Ord. O2008-55, 10-7-2008)
9-1-2: APPLICATIONS FOR PERMITS:
All applications for permits shall be made to the building commissioner and
shall be accompanied by plans and specifications in duplicate showing in detail
the work to be done. Such plans shall be verified by the signature either of
the owner of the premises or of the architect or contractor in charge of
operations.
If work for which a permit is required has already been undertaken before the
building commissioner has approved a permit application and issued a permit,
then the applicant for such permit shall pay, in addition to the regular permit
fee, a fee in the amount specified under the reinspection fee schedule for such
work.
Every application for a permit shall certify that the proposed work shall be
completed according to plans and specifications accompanying the application
within one year from the date such permit was issued, except as otherwise
specified in
9-1-7B. Failure to complete within that time period shall constitute a
violation of the building code.
(Ord. O2008-46, 8-12-2008; amd. Ord. O2024-35, 12-17-2024)
9-1-3: APPROVAL OF PLANS:
Upon receipt of a fully and properly completed application to determine whether
the proposed work will comply with all codes and ordinances applicable thereto,
including, without limitation, the provisions of this title and of the zoning
code. If upon review the building commissioner determines that the application
has not been fully and properly completed or that the proposed work would not
comply with one or more codes or ordinances applicable to such work, then the
building commissioner shall not approve such application but shall return such
application and the plans submitted therewith to the applicant, with exceptions
noted. If upon review, the building commissioner determines that the
application has been fully and properly completed, but that the application
requires the approval of the board of trustees or other board, commission or
official, then the building commissioner shall forward the application to the
appropriate board, commission or official in the manner provided therefor. Upon
the building commissioner's determination that the proposed work would comply
with all codes and ordinances applicable to such work, that the appropriate fee
has been paid and that all required approvals therefor have been obtained, the
building commissioner shall approve such application and cause a permit to be
issued therefor. Upon issuance of a permit, one set of plans shall be returned
by the building commissioner to the applicant. No permit shall be issued except
after approval of the application and plans and the payment of the fee provided
herein. (Ord. O2008-46, 8-12-2008)
9-1-4: PERMIT FEES:
   A.   Plan Review And Administrative Filing Fee:
      1.   Outside Agency: Should a plan review be required to be performed by
a third party, as determined by the village, all fees and charges related to
the performance of such plan review shall be paid by the permit applicant. The
applicant shall pay an additional twenty percent (20%) of the charges of the
plan review performed by a third party for administrative costs and plan review
performed by village personnel. A deposit shall be submitted at the time of
application based upon the anticipated total review fee as determined by the
village.
      2.   In House Plan Review Performed By Village Personnel: Plan review
performed by village personnel shall be charged at a rate of one hundred seven
dollars ($107.00) per hour, with a one hour minimum paid at the time of
application.
      3.   Expedited Reviews: The village, or a third party as determined by
the village, shall perform plan reviews on an expedited basis for new
construction, additions, and remodeling, if such expedited review is approved
by the building commissioner based upon a request by an applicant, at a rate of
one and one-half (11/2) times the rates set forth in subsections A1 and A2 of
this section.
      4.   Engineering Review And Inspection Fee: The plan review fee for the
inspection of public and private site improvements for nonresidential and
multi-family developments shall be due upon submission of final engineering
plans for such improvements. The fee shall be one percent (1%) of the
engineer’s estimate of the cost of said improvements.
      5.   Tree Plan Review Fee: Tree plan review performed by the village
arborist shall be two hundred one dollars ($201.00) and shall cover the costs
of reviewing tree plans and associated site visits.
      6.   Fees Nonrefundable: The plan review fees set forth in this section
are nonrefundable and shall be paid regardless of whether a permit is
ultimately issued.
   B.   Building Permit Fees:
      1.   New Structures: The building permit fee for new structures shall be
one dollar forty cents ($1.40) per square foot of total floor area of the
proposed new structure, including basements, attics, and garages, up to and
including twenty five thousand (25,000) square feet. The fee shall be seventy
cents ($.70) for every square foot of total floor area thereafter.
      2.   Remodeling And Alterations: Where a building permit applicant
proposes to add no new square footage, the building permit fee shall be two
percent (2%) of the value of construction. In no event shall the fee be less
than one hundred thirty-five dollars ($135.00). In setting a fee based on the
value of construction, the building commissioner may consider any of the
following:
         a.   An estimate furnished by the permit applicant;
         b.   An affidavit from the owner or the owner’s agent; or
         c.   A calculation to be made by the building commissioner based on
the most recent edition of “RS Means Square Foot Costs” book.
      3.   Permit Fees Generally: Permit fees for the following items are as
follows:

   C.   Minimum Permit Fee: The minimum fee for any permit not specified in
this section shall be one hundred thirty-five dollars ($135.00).
   D.   Fee Increase: Fees set forth in subsections A through C of this section
shall be automatically increased on January 1 of each year starting in 2019 in
accordance with the Consumer Price Index for all Urban Consumers (CPI-U) as set
by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics for the previous year. Fees shall be
rounded to the nearest nickel, and any fee over one hundred dollars ($100.00)
shall be rounded to the nearest dollar. In the event the CPI-U is unchanged or
negative for a particular year, fees shall neither increase nor decrease for
that year. A list of current fees shall be available from the Village Clerk and
from the Building Department, and will be posted on the Village’s website. In
the event that any Building Department functions are contracted to a third
party, the total fee shall include the base fee amount set forth above plus a
twenty percent (20%) administrative fee.
   E.   Additional Fee For Work Performed Without A Permit: A fee for work
initially performed without a permit in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) or fifty percent (50%) of the applicable permit fee, whichever is
greater, shall be imposed in addition to the applicable permit fee.
(Ord. O2015-18, 5-19-2015; amd. Ord. O2021-17, 5-4-2021; Ord. O2024-07, 4-2-
2024; Memorandum, 1-6-2025)
