CHAPTER 1
ZONING ORDINANCE
SECTION:
10-1-1: Zoning Ordinance
10-1-1: ZONING ORDINANCE:
The Zoning Ordinance has been adopted as a separate ordinance available from
the Village Clerk. (1981 Code)
TITLE 11
SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS
SECTION:
11-1-1: Purpose
11-1-2: Subdivision Defined
11-1-3: Enforcing Officer
11-1-4: Exceptions For Existing Subdivisions
11-1-5: Previously Platted Lots And Areas
11-1-6: Planned Developments
11-1-7: Tentative Plats
11-1-8: Procedure On Tentative Plats
11-1-9: Final Plats
11-1-10: Final Plat Requirements
11-1-11: Supporting Documents With Final Plat
11-1-12: General Rules For Subdivisions
11-1-13: Public Improvements
11-1-14: Inspection Of Improvements
11-1-15: Variations
11-1-16: Approval On Final Subdivision Plats
11-1-1: PURPOSE:
This Chapter is adopted for the purpose of regulating the construction of
subdivisions. All subdivisions shall conform to these regulations and shall be
in conformance with all applicable parts of the Comprehensive Plan Ordinance,
hereinafter referred to as the "Plan". (Ord., 2-3-1976)
11-1-2: SUBDIVISION DEFINED:
   A.   For the purposes of this Title, "subdivision" shall mean and include:
      1.   Any change, rearrangement or resubdivision in the boundary or
divisional lines of any parcel or parcels of real estate or of any public
thoroughfare; or
      2.   The platting of a parcel or tract of land into a single numbered lot
without alteration of its boundaries; or
      3.   A planned development as defined in this Code or the Hinsdale zoning
code; or
      4.   A development as now or hereafter defined in this Code.
   B.   For the purposes of this Title, "development" shall mean and include:
      1.   Construction of new building(s) or structure(s) having a total floor
area in excess of five hundred (500) square feet on any parcel of land; or
      2.   Expansion by more than twenty five percent (25%) of an existing
structure to which this Title would apply if constructed new; or
      3.   Construction on any parcel of land that will create more than three
(3) parking spaces; provided, however, that no such activity that also involves
a subdivision under subsection A of this Section shall be deemed a development
for the purposes of the administration of this Chapter.
The term "development" shall not include the construction, alteration or
remodeling of one single- family dwelling unit on one lot. (Ord. O99-19, 4-20-
1999)
11-1-3: ENFORCING OFFICER:
The enforcing officer shall be the Village Manager or his designee. (Ord., 2-3-
1976)
11-1-4: EXCEPTIONS FOR EXISTING SUBDIVISIONS:
The applicable requirements of this Chapter within the corporate limits of the
Village may be waived when the following conditions are met:
   A.   Where the proposed subdivision will not result in reducing the side
yard or rear yard of an existing building or accessory building below existing
minimum zoning requirements.
   B.   Where the proposed subdivision will not result in reducing frontage,
depth or area of any previous existing lot or parcel of land below the existing
minimum zoning requirements. (Ord., 2-3-1976)
   C.   In any residential district, when the proposed subdivision does not
result in the creation of any additional buildable lot or parcel of land. For
purposes of this subsection, a "buildable lot" or "parcel of land" is defined
as one which has the minimum lot area and dimensions such that it may be
developed pursuant to the Hinsdale zoning code. (Ord., 4-25-1989)
   D.   Where the proposed subdivision is not in a special management area as
defined in Title 12 of this Code.
   E.   Where the proposed subdivision encompasses land less than three (3)
acres of single-family residential or one acre of other zoned land. (Ord., 3-
17-1992)
The waiving of the applicable requirements of this Chapter shall be allowed by
the enforcing officer only when all the conditions specified in subsections A
through E of this Section are met, and only after a plat of the proposed
subdivision has been filed with the enforcing officer giving all necessary
information needed to determine whether the conditions specified in said
subsections A through E above are complied with. (2-3-76; amd. 3-17-92)
11-1-5: PREVIOUSLY PLATTED LOTS AND AREAS:
   A.   In the event that any property within the corporate limits of the
Village has been platted and recorded prior to the adoption of this Chapter as
buildable lots and owner or owners thereof wish to combine two (2) or more of
said lots, or all or parts of two (2) or more said lots into one building site,
which site conforms to existing zoning requirements, then the applicable
requirements of this Chapter may be waived by the enforcing officer, provided
such combination of lots or parts of lots does not leave a remainder lot or
part of a lot with a frontage, depth or area below minimum zoning requirements.
   B.   For lands outside the Village limits but within the review authority of
the Plan Commission set forth in section 10 of the Plan, the subdivision
regulations set forth in this Chapter shall not apply to the following:
      1.   The division or subdivision of land into parcels or tracts of five
(5) acres or more in size which does not involve any new streets or easements
of access;
      2.   The division of lots or blocks of less than one acre in any recorded
subdivision which does not involve any new streets or easements of access;
      3.   The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining
and contiguous land;
      4.   The conveyance of parcels of land or interests therein for use as a
right of way for railroads, pipe lines or other public utility facilities which
does not involve any new streets or easements of access;
      5.   The conveyance of land owned by a railroad or other public utility
which does not involve any new streets or easements of access;
      6.   The conveyance of land for highway or other public purposes or
grants or conveyances relating to the dedication of land for public use or
instruments relating to the vacation of land impressed with a public use;
      7.   Conveyances made to correct descriptions in prior conveyances;
      8.   The sale or exchange of parcels or tracts of land following the
division into no more than two (2) parts of a particular parcel or tract of
land existing on July 17, 1959, and not involving any new streets or easements
of access;
      9.   The sale of a single lot of less than five (5) acres from a larger
tract when a survey is made by a registered surveyor; provided, however, that
this exemption shall not apply to the sale of any subsequent lots from the same
larger tract of land, as determined by the dimensions and configuration of the
larger tract on the effective date of this Plan.
11-1-6: PLANNED DEVELOPMENTS:
This Chapter shall apply to all planned developments, as defined in the zoning
ordinance. Such developments may be recorded or registered as one lot or
parcel; specifications for public improvements and easements required under
this Chapter shall apply thereto and variations may be granted as permitted in
Section
11-1-15.
11-1-7: TENTATIVE PLATS:
Except as modified by Sections
11-1-4 and
11-1-5 above, any owner of land within the corporate limits of the Village or
within the review authority of the Plan Commission, set forth in section 10 of
the Plan, wishing to divide or subdivide the same into lots (for the purpose of
sale or assessment, or both) or wishing to dedicate streets, alleys or other
lands for public use, shall first submit to the Plan Commission six (6) copies
of a tentative plat of the proposed subdivision or dedication on a scale not
less than one hundred feet to one inch (1" = 100'). Said tentative plat shall
show the following:
   A.   Title of proposed subdivision.
   B.   Exact boundaries of property to be subdivided.
   C.   Existing buildings, structures and improvements on the property
together with and within fifty feet (50') thereof and a statement as to the
proposed use or disposition thereof.
   D.   Watercourses on or adjacent to the property.
   E.   Contour lines or two foot (2') intervals.
   F.   The name, width and location of existing roads or streets on, abutting
or intersecting the property.
   G.   The name, width and location of new roads, streets or alleys proposed
to be dedicated for public use and the width and location of utility easements
existing or proposed for public use. Also, private streets and easements must
be shown.
   H.   The layout and dimensions of lots and blocks on the property.
   I.   Proposed setback lines in accordance with applicable zoning laws.
   J.   Name of owner or sponsor of the subdivision.
   K.   Location, size and description of existing water and sewer facilities,
sidewalks, curbs and pavements on or immediately adjacent to the property.
   L.   Location and area of lands, other than public streets or alleys,
proposed to be set aside for public use such as park areas and school sites.
(2-3-76)
   M.   Location of special management areas and riparian areas.
   N.   Such other information or features that the Plan Commission may
request. (3-17-92)
The Plan Commission may, at its own discretion, waive such of the above
requirements for a tentative plat which it deems unnecessary or not pertinent
to a particular subdivision or dedication.
11-1-8: PROCEDURE ON TENTATIVE PLATS:
On submission of a tentative plat, the Plan Commission shall approve or
disapprove said plat within ninety (90) days of receipt thereof. If the
tentative plat is not satisfactory in all details as presented, the Plan
Commission may require the subdivider to make such corrections or changes as
they may request before approval of said plat. Upon the approval of a tentative
plat, such plat shall be forwarded to the Village Board for their approval or
disapproval within thirty (30) days of receipt by said Board.
11-1-9: FINAL PLATS:
The subdivider shall file application for final approval of a subdivision plat
not later than one year after a tentative plat has been approved by the Village
Board. Within sixty (60) days of the filing of the last required documents
attendant to final plat requirements, the Village Board shall approve or
disapprove the final plat.
11-1-10: FINAL PLAT REQUIREMENTS:
The final plat, as submitted to the Plan Commission, shall be in strict
accordance with approved tentative plat and shall be drawn on tracing cloth or
other approved materials to a scale of not less than one hundred feet to the
inch (1" = 100'). Three (3) white prints of the final plat shall accompany the
original tracing. The final plat shall show or otherwise satisfy the following
requirements:
   A.   All items listed in Section
11-1-7 hereof, as required for the tentative plat, except such of said items
specifically waived by the Plan Commission.
   B.   Certificate of licensed surveyor or engineer that property has been
surveyed and the plat submitted is a correct presentation of the property as it
is proposed to be divided or subdivided or dedicated and date of said
certificate.
   C.   Certificate of owner or owners in a form satisfactory to the Plan
Commission.
   D.   Proper certificates to provide for the approving signatures of the
proper officers of the Plan Commission and the Village Board and for recording
or registering signatures of the proper officials of DuPage or Cook Counties.
   E.   That all streets have been named in conformance with existing naming
plan of the Village or other adjoining roads or streets where possible.
   F.   All lot lines shall be shown and all lots and blocks shall be numbered
by progressive numbers.
   G.   Easements of any nature shall be shown and designated by measurements
as to width and length.
   H.   Sufficient dimensions, both linear and angular, in accordance with
standard surveying practice shall be shown, so as to permit retracement of any
part of the subdivision in the future without difficulty including curve data
and coordinates of boundary corners. Linear measurements shall be in feet and
decimals thereof, and angular measurements in degrees and minutes. All curved
lines in the subdivision shall have fixed radii which shall be indicated
thereon and all starting and ending points of curved lines shall be suitably
designated on the plat.
   I.   Evidence that suitable monuments, consisting of Portland cement
concrete four and one-half inches by four and one-half inches by forty two
inches (41/2" x 41/2" x 42") or approved equal have been installed at the
direction of the enforcing officer. Iron pipes or monuments are required at
block corners, at changes in direction of exterior boundaries, at angle points
in street lines exclusive of block corners and such other points as the
enforcing officer may direct. Iron pipe stakes shall not be less than three-
quarters inch (3/4") in diameter and thirty inches (30") long and shall be
installed at all corners and the beginning and ending of each fixed radius
curve except where larger stakes are required as above. The use of wooden
stakes to mark any of the above named points shall not be permitted. The
surveyor or engineer shall indicate on the plat by suitable symbol the location
and nature of all stakes or monuments in place.
   J.   That provision has been made for direct street or alley connections
with existing public streets and alleys in adjacent and abutting areas or
subdivisions that if extended would intersect this subdivision, unless
specifically waived by the Plan Commission.
   K.   The owner's certificate specified in subsection C above shall contain a
statement of dedication properly conveying for public use all streets, alleys,
school sites, parks, playgrounds, easements or other public purpose.
   L.   Any other certificates, seals and signatures or dates not enumerated
herein as required by law.
   M.   Legal description of property.
11-1-11: SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS WITH FINAL PLAT:
The final plat shall be accompanied by the following supporting documents,
except that the Plan Commission may, in its own discretion, waive submission of
such of the supporting documents or parts thereof which it deems unnecessary at
that time for final approval or which are not pertinent to a particular
subdivision: (2-3-76)
   A.   A general grading plan of the entire subdivision by means of finished
grade contours of one foot (1') intervals. (2-3-76; amd. 3-17-92)
   B.   Profiles showing existing ground levels and proposed top of finished
surface along the center line of all streets and alleys within the subdivision.
   C.   A statement signed by the subdivider setting forth in detail the public
improvements he agrees to construct at his own expense in the subdivision or
adjacent thereto, together with plans and specifications for same, prepared by
a civil engineer licensed in the State of Illinois.
   D.   A statement by the enforcing officer certifying that the improvements
proposed by the subdivider in items A, B and C noted above meet the minimum
requirements of this Chapter and all applicable regulations of the Village.
   E.   Cash deposited in escrow with the Village by the subdivider in an
amount equal to the estimated cost of the public improvements as prepared by
the engineer referred to in C above.
   F.   An affidavit certifying that the name or names of the person or persons
of said subdivision are the true, lawful and sole owners of all the land
included in the subdivision. When such an affidavit appears on the final plat
in a form satisfactory to the Plan Commission, the provisions of this
subsection may be waived.
   G.   Certificate evidence on the final plat evidencing that all real estate
taxes and special assessments currently due on all the property within the
subdivision have been paid. (2-3-76)
   H.   A storm water management permit application including developments
security and long term maintenance agreements. (3-17-92)
11-1-12: GENERAL RULES FOR SUBDIVISIONS:
   A.   Street And Alley Location And Width: For all subdivisions located
within the Village limits, the streets and alleys shown thereon and the width
thereof shall conform to the pattern of streets and alleys as set forth in the
Plan. Street right-of-way widths shall not be less than the following
dimensions: (Ord., 2-3-1976)
 
Freeways      250 feet to 400 feet
Expressways   125 feet to 175 feet
Arterials     100 feet
Local streets 66 feet
              36 feet radius where cul-de-sacs are created on existing streets
Cul-de-sacs   with a 66 foot right of way. In all other cases, a cul-de-sac
              shall require a 40 foot radius
Alleys        25 feet
 
(Ord., 2-3-1976; amd. Ord., 3-7-1978)
   Where existing rights of way of abutting streets are greater than above
standards, then such existing right- of-way widths may be used.
   B.   Easements: Where no alleys are provided, easements for the installation
and maintenance of all overhead or underground utility services including
electric, telephone, gas, water and sewage services, shall be dedicated upon
the subdivision plat. Said easements shall be not less than ten feet (10') in
width and shall be centered on the rear lot lines as far as possible, or in
such other locations as the enforcing officer and the Plan Commission may
approve, and shall be so laid out as to provide continuity of such public
utility services from block to block.
   C.   Setback Lines: For all subdivisions, setback lines, if any, shall
conform to the rules and regulations of the Village's Zoning Ordinance.
   D.   Block Sizes: In all subdivisions, blocks shall not be more than one
thousand two hundred feet (1,200') long nor less than two hundred fifty feet
(250') wide. (Ord., 2-3-1976)
   E.   Zoning Regulations: The proposed subdivision shall conform to all
applicable requirements of the Hinsdale zoning code, including, without
limitation, the regulations related to minimum lot areas and dimensions. (Ord.,
4-25-1989)
   F.   Large Lots Or Tracts: Any owner wishing to subdivide the property into
lots or tracks of an exceptionally large size shall plat the same in such
manner that any future streets that may be anticipated can be laid out along
lot lines. The Plan Commission may reserve the right to require easements for
such streets to be shown and dedicated on such subdivision. (Ord., 2-3-1976)
   G.   Land Dedication And Contribution Standards:
      1.   General Requirement:
         a.   Condition Of Subdivision Approval: As a condition of approval of
a final plat for any subdivision that is located, entirely or in part, within a
residential district or that is, or is intended to be, used, entirely or in
part, for residential purposes, the subdivider shall be required to dedicate
land for park and recreational purposes to serve the immediate and future needs
of the residents of the proposed subdivision, or to provide a cash contribution
in lieu of actual land dedication, or to provide a combination of land and cash
contributions, at the option of the Village, in accordance with this subsection
G; provided, however, that no land dedication or cash contribution in lieu
thereof shall be required for the first fifteen (15) persons of any net
increase in ultimate population in any subdivision as calculated pursuant to
this subsection G. Land shall not be artificially subdivided so as to avoid
dedication of the full amount of land or payment of the full cash contribution
in lieu of land dedication otherwise required pursuant to this subsection G.
         b.   Aggregation Of Multiple Subdivisions: Two (2) or more
subdivisions that are represented by their subdividers to be separate
subdivisions shall be aggregated and treated as a single subdivision under this
subsection G when they are determined to be part of a unified plan of
development and are physically proximate to each other. Two (2) or more
subdivisions shall be treated as a unified plan of development if one or more
of the following standards apply:
            (1)   Common Ownership Or Control: Two (2) or more of the following
standards are met:
               (A)   The same person or persons has retained or shared control
of the land in the subdivision within a period of twenty (20) years prior to
the date of submission of an application for subdivision approval but not
including any period prior to January 1, 1999;
               (B)   The same person or persons has ownership or a significant
legal, beneficial or equitable interest in the land in the subdivision or in
the development within a period of twenty (20) years prior to the date of
submission of an application for subdivision approval but not including any
period prior to January 1, 1999; or
               (C)   There is common management of the subdivisions controlling
the form of physical development or disposition of parcels in the development.
            (2)   Closeness In Time Of Development: A reasonable closeness in
time between the completion of eighty percent (80%) or less of one subdivision
and the submission to the Village or other entity with jurisdiction of a
tentative subdivision plan or application for zoning relief for the other
subdivision or subdivisions.
            (3)   Shared Infrastructure: The sharing of infrastructure between
or among the subdivisions, such as streets, sidewalks, sanitary sewers, water
mains, or storm sewers and drainage systems.
            (4)   Common Sales Efforts: A common advertising scheme or
promotional plan is used for the subdivisions sought to be aggregated.
         c.   Condition Of Occupancy Permit: No occupancy permit shall be
issued for any structure on the land in the subdivision until such conveyance
or contribution has been acknowledged and received by the Village Manager.
      2.   Density Formula:
         a.   Population Table: The Table of Estimated Ultimate Population Per
Dwelling Unit, set forth in this Section as Table 11-1, shall be used as
provided in this subsection G to calculate the required dedication of land for
park and recreational purposes or for cash contributions in lieu thereof,
unless a written objection thereto is filed by the subdivider with the Village
Manager pursuant to subsection G2c of this Section.

   Note: The determination of the number of bedrooms contained in a building
shall be made by the Village Manager. Rooms designated by a subdivider as
"den", "library", "study", "sewing room", "exercise room", or the like may be
designated by the Village Manager as bedrooms if they are suitable for such
accommodations.
         b.   Presumed Density Formula: In applying Table 11-1 of this Section
to a proposed subdivision for which the types of units and number of bedrooms
cannot reasonably be determined from the data and materials on file with the
Village, the following types of units and bedroom data shall be used, unless a
written objection thereto is filed by the subdivider with the village manager
pursuant to subsection G2c of this section:

                                         applicable zoning.
Multiple-family dwellings in the R-5 and Equal mix of 2 and 3 bedroom units at
R-6 districts:                           maximum unit density permitted by
                                         applicable zoning.
 
         c.   Objection To Density Formulas: If the subdivider files a written
objection with the village manager to the use of table 11-1 of this section or
the presumed density formula set forth in subsection G2b of this section, the
subdivider shall submit, at the subdivider's sole cost and expense, a thorough
and comprehensive demographic study showing the estimated population to be
generated by the proposed subdivision. The village board shall make the final
determination as to the density formula and estimated population that shall
apply to the proposed subdivision, which final decision shall be based on the
demographic study submitted by the subdivider and all other facts and
circumstances relevant to the issue as determined and required by the village
board. Nothing in this subsection G2c shall be construed as limiting or
preventing the village board from utilizing table 11-1 of this section or the
presumed density formula set forth in subsection G2b of this section for any
proposed subdivision. (Ord. O99-19, 4-20-1999)
      3.   Criteria For Park Land Dedication:
         a.   Calculation Of Land Required To Be Dedicated: The amount of land
required to be dedicated for park and recreational purposes for a proposed
subdivision shall be a direct function of the ultimate population density of
that subdivision. The requirement shall be based on a standard of fifteen (15)
acres of land per one thousand (1,000) net increase in ultimate population,
computed in accordance with subsection G2 and table 11-1 of this section. (Ord.
O2004-55, 11-16-2004)
         b.   Location Of Land To Be Dedicated: The location of the land to be
dedicated for park and recreational purposes for the proposed subdivision
pursuant to this subsection G shall be determined by the village board after
receipt of a recommendation by the plan commission. The determination shall be
based on such factors as the plan commission and the village board shall deem
appropriate, including specifically, but without limitation, the availability
of land, the suitability of any particular land for park and recreational
purposes as opposed to use for other development, the location of the land
relative to population concentrations, and the proximity of the land to other
park or recreational lands.
         c.   Minimum Size Of Dedicated Land: The minimum size of any land to
be dedicated for park and recreational purposes shall be ten thousand (10,000)
square feet in area and no dimension shall be less than one hundred feet
(100'); provided, however, that the plan commission may recommend and the
village board may approve dedications of a smaller size or dimension when
required by the specific plans of the proposed subdivision and when the
usefulness of the smaller area for park and recreational purposes is clearly
demonstrated. Nothing in this subsection G3c shall require the dedication of
any land in excess of the amount otherwise required by subsection G3a of this
section.
         d.   On Site Storage Prohibited: No materials or equipment, including,
without limitation, topsoil or other soil materials, shall be stored on any
land that has been dedicated, or that has been designated for dedication, to
the village for park or recreational purposes pursuant to this subsection G
without the express prior written consent of the village.
         e.   Detention And Retention Areas Not Qualified: No storm water
detention or retention area shall qualify as land suitable for dedication for
park and recreational purposes, unless the suitability of such land for park
and recreational purposes as a secondary use is clearly demonstrated to the
satisfaction of the village board.
         f.   Private Common Open Space And Recreational Areas:
            (1)   When private open space is made permanently available for use
on an equal and common basis to every resident in the proposed subdivision at a
proportionate share of the cost of maintenance, and such open space is
specifically intended and designed to meet the recreational needs of the
subdivision and is depicted on the final plat for the proposed subdivision and
recorded against the subject property ("private common open space"), then a one
hundred percent (100%) credit toward the park land dedication requirement of
this subsection shall be allowed to the extent of such private common open
space.
            (2)   If the total acreage of private common open space for the
proposed subdivision equals the total acreage required to be dedicated for park
and recreational purposes pursuant to this subsection, then such requirement
shall be deemed to have been fulfilled by the provision of such private common
open space.
            (3)   If the private common open space for the proposed subdivision
is not adequately or property maintained, at any time, to the satisfaction of
the Village Board, or if such private common open space is not made available
for use on an equal and common basis to every resident in the subdivision at a
proportionate share of the cost of maintenance, or ceases to be made so
available for use on such basis, then the private common open space shall be
dedicated by the owner to the public for public park and recreational purposes
upon direction by the Village Board, in the form of a resolution or ordinance
duly adopted, that such a dedication be made.
            (4)   Prior to approval of the final plat, the subdivider shall
prepare and record covenants establishing the provisions of this subsection
G3f, which covenants shall be duly executed by all owners of the land and all
mortgage holders, if any, and delivered to the Village for recording. Each such
covenant shall recite that it shall be enforceable by suit in equity brought by
the Village, its successors, if any, or by any interested person.
      4.   Criteria For Payment In Lieu Of Land Dedication:
         a.   General Qualification: In the event that a proposed subdivision
is small and the resulting required land dedication is too small, in the
determination of the Village Board, to be practical, or when the Village Board
finds that the available land is inappropriate for park and recreational
purposes, then the Village shall have the authority to require the subdivider
to pay a cash contribution in lieu of the otherwise required land dedications,
in accordance with the standards of this subsection G4.
         b.   Definition Of Fair-Market Value: The cash contributions in lieu
of land shall be based on the fair-market value of the acres of land in the
proposed subdivision, which fair-market value shall be determined by an
appraiser hired by the Village. The Village's expenses related to the hiring of
an appraiser for the purposes of determining the fair-market value shall be
reimbursed to the Village by the subdivider.
         c.   Objection To Fair-Market Value Determination: If the subdivider
or any other affected person files a written objection with the Village Manager
to the fair-market value as established pursuant to subsection G4b of this
Section, the subdivider or other affected person shall submit, at his or her
sole cost and expense, a written appraisal professionally prepared by a Member
of the Appraisal Institute of America (MAI). The appraisal shall show the fair
market value of improved land in the area of the proposed subdivision. The
Village Board shall make the final determination as to the fair market value of
such improved land, which final determination shall be based on the appraisal
or other information submitted by the subdivider or other affected person
involved, and any response thereto filed by the subdivider or other affected
person, and all other facts and circumstances relevant to the issue as
determined and required by the Village Board. Nothing in this subsection G4c
shall be construed as limiting or preventing the Village Board from utilizing
the fair-market value as established in subsection G4b of this Section for any
proposed subdivision.
         d.   Disposition Of Cash Contributions:
            (1)   Cash contributions in lieu of park land dedications shall be
held in trust by the Village, or other public body designated by the Village,
solely for use in the acquisition or development of park and recreational land
to serve the immediate or future needs of the residents of the proposed
subdivision or for the improvement of other existing local park and
recreational sites.
            (2)   Funds held in trust shall be kept separate from all other
funds and shall be accounted for in the appropriate manner.
         e.   Refund Of Cash Contributions: If any portion of a cash
contribution in lieu of a park land dedication is not expended for the purposes
set forth herein within seven (7) years after the date of receipt of such
contribution by the Village, then that cash contribution shall be refunded to
the subdivider who made such contribution, or its successor or assign.
      5.   Criteria For Combination Land Dedication And Cash Payment: A
combination of land dedication and cash contribution in lieu of land dedication
may be required when appropriate as determined by the Village Board, including,
without limitation, in the following two (2) circumstances:
         a.   Inadequate Land: The proposed subdivision has some but not enough
adequate land to meet the dedication requirements of this subsection. That
portion of the land within the proposed subdivision that is adequate for park
land shall be dedicated as provided in this subsection, and a cash contribution
shall be required for any additional land that would have been required to be
dedicated pursuant to this subsection.
         b.   Previous Acquisition: A major part of the local park or
recreational site already has been acquired and only a small parcel of land is
needed from the proposed subdivision to complete the site. Such parcel shall be
acquired by dedication, and a cash contribution shall be required for any
additional land that would have been required to be dedicated pursuant to this
subsection.
      6.   Reservation Of Additional Land: When the Village's Official
Comprehensive Plan or other applicable standard of the Village requires a
larger amount of park and recreational land in a particular subdivision than
the subdivider is otherwise required to dedicate pursuant to the terms of this
subsection, then the land needed in excess of the otherwise required dedication
shall be reserved by the subdivider for subsequent purchase by the Village or
other public body designated by the Village, provided that such acquisition is
started within one year after the date of approval of the final plat for the
proposed subdivision.
      7.   Combining With Adjoining Subdivisions: For proposed subdivisions of
forty (40) acres or less, the otherwise applicable park and recreational land
dedication may be combined, where practical as determined by the Village Board,
with dedications for the same purposes from adjoining subdivisions or
developments to produce usable park or recreational areas.
      8.   Topography And Grading: The slope, topography, and geology of a site
to be dedicated pursuant to the requirements of this subsection, as well as its
surroundings, shall be suitable for the intended purpose of the site. Grading
on dedicated land shall not differ greatly from surrounding land. No removal of
existing topsoil shall be permitted.
      9.   Improved Sites: All sites shall be dedicated in a condition ready
for full service of electrical, telecommunications, gas, water, sewer and
streets (including curb and gutter and enclosed drainage), as applicable to the
location of the site, or acceptable provisions shall be made therefor.
      10.   Dedication Required As Part Of Annexation Agreement: Unless waived
by the Village Board in its sole and absolute discretion, the dedication of
land, or cash contributions in lieu thereof, required by this subsection also
shall be required as a condition of the annexation of any land to the Village
for residential purposes. However, the same shall not be required as condition
to an amendment of an annexation agreement unless the Village Board finds from
a consideration of the purposes of this subsection that such dedications or
payments should be required because of increased burdens to be placed on the
park system over and above those covered by the dedications and cash
contributions made or provided for in connection with the original annexation
agreement. If the Village Board does so find, then additional dedications or
cash contributions shall be required, but only to the extent necessary to cover
the shortage resulting from such increased burdens. Dedications of land or cash
contributions in lieu thereof as specified in any annexation agreement that
substantially comply with the requirements of this subsection shall be deemed
to have fulfilled the dedication requirements of this subsection.
      11.   Dedication At Time Of Approval Of Final Plat: Approval of any final
plat of subdivision shall be conditioned on the dedication of land, or cash
donations in lieu thereof, as required by this subsection. When a subdivision
is to be developed over a period of years, dedication of required land may be
made after completion of a portion of the subdivision provided that an escrow
fund satisfactory to the Village has been established to guarantee the
conveyance of land after completion of such portion of the subdivision.
      12.   Title To Dedicated Park Land:
         a.   General Requirement: All sites to be dedicated pursuant to this
subsection shall be conveyed to the Village either by warranty or trustee's
deed, or such form of conveyance as the Village shall require. The subdivider
shall be responsible for payment of all real estate taxes to the date of
conveyance, including any agricultural rollback taxes that might be extended or
levied against such sites. In the discretion of the Village, a commitment for
title insurance issued by a company authorized to do business in Illinois may
be required as evidence of clear title.
         b.   Park Land: Conveyance of park land dedications shall occur only
after or simultaneously with the passage of an ordinance or resolution by the
Village, in which it indicates that the land will be accepted by the Village,
for park purposes.
   H.   Lands Designated For Public Use: In addition to any lands required to
be dedicated or reserved pursuant to subsection G of this Section, all
subdividers may be required to set aside a certain portion of land to be used
for public purpose. The Village Board shall proceed to acquire the land so
designated by purchase, or commence proceedings to acquire by condemnation
within one year from the date of approval of the subdivision plat. If the
Village Board fails to act within the one year period, the land designated for
public use may then be used by the owners in any other manner consistent with
this Plan. (Ord. O99-19, 4-20-1999)

11-1-13: PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS:
The following improvements will be required for all subdivisions under the
jurisdiction of this Plan. (Ord., 2-3-1976)
   A.   Pavement, Curbs, Gutters: On both sides of all unimproved streets
located wholly or partially within a subdivision and abutting said subdivision,
the subdivider shall install at his own expense combination concrete curb and
gutter and pavement. Plans and profiles or such work shall be prepared by an
Illinois licensed professional engineer (civil) and shall conform to the
Illinois Department of Transportation Specifications for Road and Bridge
Construction, as amended from time to time provided, however, that all streets
and alleys shall be constructed to the following minimum structural numbers as
said structural numbers are defined by the Illinois Department of
Transportation Design Manual, as amended from time to time:
 
                                                 Minimum Structural Number
Streets:                                          3
Alleys abutting property zoned in buffer zone, or 2.25
commercial districts:
Alleys abutting property zoned in residence       2
districts:
 
   All paved streets shall be not less than twenty eight feet (28') back to
back of curbs. The Plan Commission may recommend, the Village Board of Trustees
may require under the circumstances surrounding any proposed subdivision, that
paved streets be greater than twenty eight feet (28') back to back of curbs if
the Board of Trustees deems such greater width necessary or advisable based on
current and projected traffic volumes and the Illinois Department of
Transportation Design Manual, as amended from time to time. (Ord., 9-28-1987)
   B.   Sidewalks: All subdividers are required to install, at their own
expense, concrete sidewalks conforming to Village standards within or abutting
a subdivision. Plans and profiles shall be prepared by an Illinois licensed
professional engineer in accordance with the specifications in the Illinois
Department of Transportation Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction,
the current edition, which is made a part of this Chapter by reference. (Ord.,
2-3-1976)
   C.   Trees Required In Parkways: The subdivider shall plant, at his or her
own expense, trees in all parkways within or abutting the subdivision averaging
a distance of not greater than fifty feet (50') apart, except that existing
trees may be used in lieu of new trees to fulfill the requirements of this
subsection if such existing trees are reviewed and approved as suitable by the
Village Manager. Such trees shall be planted seven feet (7') from the street
edge of the parkway or twelve feet (12') from the private property line if no
sidewalks are required by this Chapter or otherwise installed by the
subdivider. The Plan Commission shall approve the location for all trees
required by this subsection along every right of way wider than sixty six feet
(66'). The subdivider shall choose various types of trees from among the
following varieties in fulfilling the requirements of this subsection:
Amur Maple            Sugar Maple:
Black Maple           Green Mountain
Cockspur Hawthorn     River Birch
European Alder        Hackberry:
Whitespire Birch      Autumn Purple
European Hophornbeam  White Ash
Freeman Maple:        Blue Oak
Autumn Blaze          Green Ash:
Emerald Lustre        Marshall Seedless
Norway Maple          Summit
Ginkgo (male only)    Honeylocust:
Kentucky Coffeetree   Shademaster
Swamp White Oak       English Oak
Bur Oak               Bald Cypress
Chinkapin Oak         Littleleaf Linden:
Redmond Linden        Greenspire
Silver Linden         Japanese Zilkova
 
   The subdivider shall submit a tree planting plan to the enforcing officer
for approval prior to approval of the final plat of subdivision. Such tree
planting plan shall show the location, size, and variety of each tree to be
planted and of each existing tree proposed by the subdivider to be used in lieu
of the planting of a new tree. All trees used to fulfill the requirements of
this subsection C shall be not less than two inches (2") trunk diameter in
size, measured at fifty four inches (54") above ground level ("diameter at
breast height"). (3-15-94)
   D.   Street Name Signs: The Village will order and install one street sign
at all new intersections created by such subdivision. The subdivider shall
reimburse the Village for all expenses associated with the above.
   E.   Water Supply: The water system of the Village shall be extended
throughout or adjacent to the entire subdivision by the subdivider, at his own
expense, in such a manner that every lot in such subdivision may be serviced by
means of a service connection from water mains within the frontage or side
yards of each lot. The water system must be a looped system providing two (2)
independent sources of water service. The water system shall be built in
accordance with the Village's Standard Specifications for Water Main
Installation, the current edition.
   F.   Sanitary Sewers: The subdivider shall, at his own expense, install a
complete system of sanitary sewers throughout or adjacent to the subdivision in
such a manner as to render same accessible to every lot within its own
frontage. In no event shall the Plan Commission approve any subdivision that
does not provide for sanitary sewer service to every lot therein. Sewer systems
shall be built in accordance with Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer
Main Construction in Illinois, Second Edition, November 1973, as amended from
time to time, which are made part of this Plan by reference.
   G.   Storm Sewers: The Plan Commission shall require the installation of a
storm sewer system by the subdivider at his own expense as a condition for
approval of the plat, which system shall be separate from any sanitary sewer
system. Plans and profiles of storm sewer systems shall be prepared in
accordance with Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction
in Illinois as amended from time to time, which are made a part of this Plan by
reference. (2-3-76)
   H.   Storm water retention shall meet the requirements of Title 12 of this
Code. (3-17-92)
   I.   Public Utilities: All public utility installations shall be
underground. These public utilities shall include but are not limited to
electric, telephone, gas and cable TV underground. Street lighting shall be
provided at the corners and the midblocks. Street lights shall conform to the
standards of the power company.
   J.   Approval of Plans for Improvements: All plans, specifications and
contracts for public improvements inside the corporate limits required by this
Chapter shall be approved by the enforcing officer prior to installation of any
of said improvements. (2-3-76)
11-1-14: INSPECTION OF IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   Appointment of Inspector: If, in the opinion of the enforcing officer,
it is necessary to have the public improvement required herein under more or
less continuous inspection and supervision and requiring services beyond the
normal duties of Village employees, he may appoint a qualified person as an
inspector.
   B.   Payment of Inspection Fees: It shall be the responsibility of the
subdivider to pay the actual cost of said inspector's compensation including
said inspector's direct salary and fringe benefits.
   C.   Method of Payment: In the event that an inspector is appointed, the
enforcing officer shall require the subdivider, prior to starting any
improvements requiring inspection, to pay to the Village Collector a sum which
the enforcing officer estimates will cover the costs of said inspection. In the
event the amount originally paid is not sufficient, the subdivider shall pay
the additional amount required to finish the work; or if the amount originally
paid is more than required, the surplus shall be returned to the subdivider
without interest. (2-3-76)
11-1-15: VARIATIONS:
The Plan Commission may recommend and the Board of Trustees may approve one or
more variations from the requirements of Sections
11-1-7,
11-1-10,
11-1-11,
11-1-12, and
11-1-13 of this Chapter for a plat of subdivision; provided, however, that no
such variation shall be granted by the Board of Trustees that would detract
from or adversely affect the general plan, intent, or spirit of this Chapter or
of any building or zoning regulations applicable to the property that is the
subject of such plat of subdivision. Any such recommendation by the Plan
Commission shall be made in writing and be transmitted to the Board of Trustees
along with the Plan Commission's recommendation or other action on such plat of
subdivision. (10-4-88)
11-1-16: APPROVAL OF FINAL SUBDIVISION PLATS:
   A.   Approval by Plan Commission: After approval of a final subdivision plat
by the Plan Commission, the certificate thereon denoting said approval and date
thereof shall be signed by the chairman of the Plan Commission and attested by
the secretary. The secretary shall then transmit the approved final plat to the
Village Board together with a document of transmittal calling the Board's
attention to all variations (if any) approved by the Plan Commission and
setting forth its reasons for approving said variations and conveying to the
Board such other information concerning the subdivision as the Plan Commission
may deem necessary or advisable. With the approved final plat, the secretary of
the Plan Commission shall also transmit to the Village Board the subdivider's
agreement with respect to improvements, the approval of the enforcing officer
of all said improvements, together with plans, specifications, estimates and
escrow agreements, and all other documents, certificates and papers pertaining
to the final plat and the subdivision platted thereon; except that the Village
Board may waive the requirement as to receiving documents at that time
pertaining to proposed improvements as specified immediately above and approve
the final plat without said documents; provided, that all such required
documents shall be delivered to the enforcing officer before the final plat is
recorded. (2-3-76)
   B.   Approval by Board of Trustees: When the Board of Trustees is satisfied
with the final plat and with all proposed improvements, conditions, and
documents as submitted pertaining to the subdivision platted therein, the Board
of Trustees shall approve the final plat and authorize and direct the Village
President and the Village Clerk to sign the "approved" certificate on the final
plat, including the date of such signature, and to affix the Village Seal
thereto. The Board of Trustees' approval of the final plat may be subject to
appropriate conditions that must be fulfilled prior to the recording of the
final plat, such as, without limitation, submission by the subdivider of cash
as required by Section
11-1-11 of this Code to ensure the proper installation of all public
improvements attendant to the subdivision. Before the Village Clerk shall sign
or affix the Village Seal to the final plat, the subdivider shall fulfill all
conditions imposed by the Board of Trustees on the approval of the final plat
and, in addition, shall pay to the Village Clerk the fee of twenty dollars
($20.00) for each of the first five (5) lots platted on the final plat and five
dollars ($5.00) for each lot in excess of five (5) lots, but in no event shall
the total fee be less than fifty dollars ($50.00). Such fee shall be in
addition to the recording fees required pursuant to subsection C of this
Section.
   C.   Recording of Plat; Fees; Time Limit: The Village Clerk shall retain
each approved final plat until the subdivider has 1) fulfilled all conditions
imposed by the Board of Trustees on the approval of the final plat, and 2)
submitted to the Village cash to ensure the proper installation of all public
improvements attendant to the subdivision as required by Section
11-1-11 of this Title, and 3) deposited all escrow funds, inspection fees, and
other materials and documents that may be required with the final plat, and 4)
paid the fee provided in subsection B of this Section, and 5) paid to the
Village Clerk a sum estimated by the Village Clerk to be the cost of recording
the final plat. The Village Clerk shall cause the final plat to be recorded,
but only after all such requirements have been fulfilled. The original final
plat shall be retained permanently in the Village's files. No final plat
approval shall be valid for a period longer than one year unless all conditions
attached to such final plat approval have been fulfilled and the final plat has
been recorded. (3-15-94)
   D.   Conflict of Jurisdiction: The Plan Commission claims full jurisdiction
over platting of subdivisions and improvements thereon on all subdivisions
outside the Village limits, except as modified herein, within the boundaries
described in section 10 of the Plan. However, in the matter of water supply and
sewage disposal for individual lots or subdivisions as a whole where it is not
feasible to supply such lots or subdivisions with water or sewage service from
existing public water or sewage systems, the said Plan Commission waives
jurisdiction over such water and sewer installations in favor of control of
same by the county in which located. The enforcing officer shall notify the
proper county authorities in such circumstances. (2-3-76)

FLOOD CONTROL REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL REGULATIONS

12-1-2: Reference To Watershed Plans

12-1-1: ADOPTION OF DUPAGE COUNTY ORDINANCE:
The DuPage County stormwater and floodplain ordinance (“DuPage County
ordinance”), as contained in section 15-1-1 et seq., of the DuPage County code,
as amended and approved by the DuPage County Board effective May 15, 2019, and
as may be amended in the future, is hereby adopted by reference for the DuPage
County and Cook County portions of the village. The DuPage County ordinance is
attached as exhibit A to the ordinance codified herein and incorporated by
reference. Three (3) copies of the DuPage County ordinance shall be kept on
file for public inspection in the office of the village clerk for public use,
inspection and examination. If the provisions of the DuPage County ordinance,
as adopted, conflict with or contravene any provision of this title, the
provisions of this title shall control. (Ord. O2010-35, 7-13-2010; amd. Ord.
2019-20, 7-16-2019)
12-1-2: REFERENCE TO WATERSHED PLANS:
The following major watershed divisions are identified for detailed watershed
studies:
   A.   Salt Creek watershed; and
   B.   Des Plaines River tributaries watershed. (Ord. O2006-43, 6-20-2006)
12-1-3: VILLAGE ENGINEER TO ADMINISTER:
The village engineer or his or her designee shall administer the implementation
and enforcement of this title. (Ord. O2006-43, 6-20-2006)
12-1-4: SITE RUNOFF REQUIREMENT EXCEPTIONS:
All developments in the village shall comply with the site runoff requirements
of this title except those in which the parcels being developed total less than
one acre; provided, however, that, where the parcels being developed total less
than three (3) acres and the development is for single-family residential uses,
a waiver of particular requirements may be granted by the president and board
of trustees when requested by the developer in writing and when the requested
waiver: a) complies with all of the applicable variance standards of this
title; or b) provides land use, aesthetic or natural benefits that would not
otherwise be achievable by compliance with the requirement requested to be
waived. (Ord. O2006-43, 6-20-2006)
12-1-5: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A stormwater management permit shall be required if the development disturbs
more than two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of ground cover, unless
the development solely involves one or more of the following:
   A.   Cultivation, conservation measures, or gardening; or
   B.   Installation, renovation, or replacement of a septic system, potable
water service line, or other utility to serve an existing structure; or
   C.   Excavation or removal of vegetation in rights of way or public utility
easements for the purpose of installing or maintaining utilities; or
   D.   Maintenance, repair, or at grade replacement of existing lawn areas not
otherwise requiring a stormwater permit under this title. (Ord. O2006-43, 6-20-
2006)
12-1-6: GROUND AREA SLOPE:
No ground area within any required side yard shall have a slope of greater than
ten percent (10%) measured along a line drawn perpendicular to the "side lot
line" from the side lot line to the "side yard line", as those terms are
defined in the Hinsdale zoning code. (Ord. O2007-78, 11-29-2007)
12-1-7: FLOOD INSURANCE RATE MAPS AND FLOOD INSURANCE STUDIES:
Current editions of the flood insurance rate maps and flood insurance studies
shall be used in conjunction with the DuPage County countywide stormwater and
floodplain ordinance in accordance with the following table:
